text: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth was formless and void, darkness was over the surface of the deep, and the Spirit of God was moving over the surface of the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.
speaker: God

text: God saw that the light was good, and God separated the light from the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: God called the light Day, and the darkness He called Night. So the evening and the morning were the first day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be an expanse in the midst of the waters, and let it separate the waters from the waters.”
speaker: God

text: So God made the expanse and separated the waters which were under the expanse from the waters which were above the expanse. And it was so.
speaker: Narrator

text: God called the expanse Heaven. So the evening and the morning were the second day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the waters under the heavens be gathered together into one place, and let the dry land appear.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: God called the dry land Earth, and the gathering together of the waters He called Seas. Then God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the earth produce vegetation: plants yielding seed and fruit trees on the earth yielding fruit after their kind with seed in them.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: The earth produced vegetation, plants yielding seed after their kind and trees yielding fruit with seed in them after their kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the evening and the morning were the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said, “Let there be lights in the expanse of the heavens to separate the day from the night, and let them be signs to indicate seasons, and days, and years.
speaker: God

text: Let them be lights in the expanse of the heavens to give light on the earth.” And it was so.
speaker: Narrator

text: God made two great lights: the greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night. He made the stars also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God set them in the expanse of the heavens to give light on the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness. Then God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the evening and the morning were the fourth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the waters swarm with swarms of living creatures and let the birds fly above the earth in the open expanse of the heavens.”
speaker: God

text: So God created great sea creatures and every living thing that moves, with which the waters swarmed, according to their kind, and every winged bird according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God blessed them, saying, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the waters in the seas, and let the birds multiply on the earth.”
speaker: God

text: So the evening and the morning were the fifth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the earth bring forth living creatures according to their kinds: livestock, and creeping things, and beasts of the earth according to their kinds.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: So God made the beasts of the earth according to their kind, and the livestock according to their kind, and everything that creeps on the earth according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let us make man in our image, after our likeness, and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the birds of the air, and over the livestock, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creeps on the earth.”
speaker: God
Narrator

text: God blessed them and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply, and replenish the earth and subdue it. Rule over the fish of the sea and over the birds of the air and over every living thing that moves on the earth.”
speaker: God

text: Then God said, “See, I have given you every plant yielding seed which is on the face of all the earth and every tree which has fruit yielding seed. It shall be food for you.
speaker: God

text: To every beast of the earth and to every bird of the air and to everything that creeps on the earth which has the breath of life in it, I have given every green plant for food.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: God saw everything that He had made, and indeed it was very good. So the evening and the morning were the sixth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the heavens and the earth, and all their hosts, were finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day God completed His work which He had done, and He rested on the seventh day from all His work which He had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it He had rested from all His work which He had created and made.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the account of the heavens and the earth when they were created.
In the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text: no shrub of the field was yet on the earth, and no plant of the field had yet sprouted, for the Lord God had not caused it to rain on the earth, and there was no man to cultivate the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a mist arose from the earth and watered the whole surface of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God formed man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living being.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God planted a garden in the east, in Eden, and there He placed the man whom He had formed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Out of the ground the Lord God made to grow every tree that is pleasant to the sight and good for food. The tree of life was also in the midst of the garden, along with the tree of knowledge of good and evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: A river flowed out of Eden to water the garden, and from there it parted and became four rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the first is Pishon; it encompasses the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold of that land is good; bdellium and the onyx stone are there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the second river is Gihon; it encompasses the whole land of Cush.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the third river is Tigris; it goes toward the east of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God took the man and put him in the garden of Eden to till it and to keep it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord God commanded the man, saying, “Of every tree of the garden you may freely eat,
speaker: God

text: but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil you shall not eat, for in the day that you eat from it you will surely die.”
speaker: God

text: Then the Lord God said, “It is not good that the man should be alone. I will make him a helper suitable for him.”
speaker: God

text: Out of the ground the Lord God formed every beast of the field and every bird of the sky, and brought them to the man to see what he would call them. Whatever the man called every living creature, that was its name.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man gave names to all the livestock, to the birds of the sky, and to every beast of the field, but for Adam there was not found a helper suitable for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall on Adam, and he slept. Then He took one of his ribs and closed up the place with flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the rib which the Lord God had taken from man, He made into a woman, and He brought her to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Adam said,
“This is now bone of my bones
    and flesh of my flesh;
she will be called Woman,
    for she was taken out of Man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore a man will leave his father and his mother and be joined to his wife, and they will become one flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were both naked, the man and his wife, and were not ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the serpent was more subtle than any beast of the field which the Lord God had made. And he said to the woman, “Has God said, ‘You shall not eat of any tree of the garden’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the woman said to the serpent, “We may eat of the fruit from the trees of the garden;
speaker: Narrator

text: but from the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of the garden, God has said, ‘You will not eat of it, nor will you touch it, or else you will die.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the serpent said to the woman, “You surely will not die!
speaker: Narrator

text: For God knows that on the day you eat of it your eyes will be opened and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the woman saw that the tree was good for food, that it was pleasing to the eyes and a tree desirable to make one wise, she took of its fruit and ate; and she gave to her husband with her, and he ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the eyes of both were opened, and they knew that they were naked. So they sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they heard the sound of the Lord God walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and the man and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the Lord God among the trees of the garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God called to the man and said to him, “Where are you?”
speaker: God

text: He said, “I heard Your voice in the garden and was afraid because I was naked, so I hid myself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And He said, “Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree of which I commanded you not to eat?”
speaker: God

text: The man said, “The woman whom You gave to be with me, she gave me fruit of the tree, and I ate.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord God said to the woman, “What have you done?”
And the woman said, “The serpent deceived me, and I ate.”
speaker: God

text:
The Lord God said to the serpent: “Because you have done this,
You are cursed above all livestock,
    and above every beast of the field;
you will go on your belly,
    and you will eat dust
    all the days of your life.
speaker: God

text:
I will put enmity
    between you and the woman,
    and between your offspring and her offspring;
he will bruise your head,
    and you will bruise his heel.”
speaker: God

text:
To the woman He said,
“I will greatly multiply your pain in childbirth,
    and in pain you will bring forth children;
your desire will be for your husband,
    and he will rule over you.”
speaker: God

text:
And to Adam He said, “Because you have listened to the voice of your wife and have eaten from the tree about which I commanded you, saying, ‘You shall not eat of it,’
Cursed is the ground on account of you;
    in hard labor you will eat of it
    all the days of your life.
speaker: God

text:
Thorns and thistles it will bring forth for you,
    and you will eat the plants of the field.
speaker: Narrator
God

text: The man called his wife’s name Eve because she was the mother of all the living.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God made garments of skins for both Adam and his wife and clothed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God said, “The man has become like one of us, knowing good and evil. And now, he might reach out his hand, and take also from the tree of life, and eat, and live forever”—
speaker: God

text: therefore the Lord God sent him out from the garden of Eden, to till the ground from which he was taken.
speaker: God

text: He drove the man out, and at the east of the garden of Eden He placed the cherubim and a flaming sword which turned in every direction, to guard the way to the tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam had relations with his wife Eve, and she conceived, gave birth to Cain and said, “I have gotten a man with the help of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she gave birth again to his brother Abel.
And Abel was a keeper of flocks, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the course of time Cain brought an offering to the Lord of the fruit of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abel also brought the firstborn of his flock and of their fat portions. And the Lord had respect for Abel and for his offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: but for Cain and for his offering, He did not have respect. And Cain was very angry and his countenance fell.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Cain, “Why are you angry? Why is your countenance fallen?
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do well, shall you not be accepted? But if you do not do well, sin is crouching at the door. It desires to dominate you, but you must rule over it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain told Abel his brother. And it came about, when they were in the field, that Cain rose up against his brother Abel and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to Cain, “Where is Abel your brother?”
He said, “I do not know. Am I my brother’s keeper?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And then He said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood is crying out to Me from the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are cursed from the ground which opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: From now on when you till the ground, it will not yield for you its best. You will be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Cain said to the Lord, “My punishment is more than I can bear.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have driven me out this day from the face of the earth, and from your face will I be hidden; and I will be a fugitive and a vagabond in the earth, and it will happen that anyone who finds me will kill me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to him, “Therefore whoever kills Cain, vengeance will be taken on him sevenfold.” Then the Lord put a mark upon Cain, so that no one finding him would kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Cain went out from the presence of the Lord and settled in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain had relations with his wife, and she conceived and gave birth to Enoch. He built a city and called the name of the city after the name of his son, Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Enoch was born Irad, and Irad was the father of Mehujael, and Mehujael was the father of Methushael, and Methushael was the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech took two wives. The name of one was Adah, and the name of the other Zillah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah gave birth to Jabal. He was the father of those who dwell in tents and have livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brother’s name was Jubal. He was the father of all those who play the harp and flute.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zillah gave birth to Tubal-Cain, a forger of every tool of bronze and iron. The sister of Tubal-Cain was Naamah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lamech said to his wives:
“Adah and Zillah, hear my voice,
    you wives of Lamech, and listen to my speech.
For I have killed a man for wounding me,
    a young man who hurt me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If Cain will be avenged sevenfold,
    then truly Lamech seventy-sevenfold.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam had relations with his wife again, and she had another son and called his name Seth, for she said, “God has granted me another offspring instead of Abel because Cain killed him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
To Seth also was born a son, and he called his name Enosh.
At that time men began to call on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the book of the generations of Adam.
In the day when God created man, He made him in the likeness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He created them male and female. He blessed them and called them Mankind in the day when they were created.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam lived a hundred and thirty years and became the father of a son in his own likeness, after his own image, and called his name Seth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The days of Adam after he became the father of Seth were eight hundred years, and he had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred and thirty years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seth lived one hundred and five years and became the father of Enosh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seth lived after the birth of Enosh eight hundred and seven years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Seth were nine hundred and twelve years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enosh lived ninety years and became the father of Kenan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enosh lived after the birth of Kenan eight hundred and fifteen years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Enosh were nine hundred and five years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan lived seventy years and became the father of Mahalalel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan lived after the birth of Mahalalel eight hundred and forty years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Kenan were nine hundred and ten years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahalalel lived sixty-five years and became the father of Jared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahalalel lived after the birth of Jared eight hundred and thirty years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Mahalalel were eight hundred and ninety-five years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jared lived one hundred and sixty-two years and became the father of Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jared lived after the birth of Enoch eight hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Jared were nine hundred and sixty-two years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch lived sixty-five years and became the father of Methuselah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch walked with God after the birth of Methuselah for three hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Enoch were three hundred and sixty-five years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch walked with God, and then he was no more because God took him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Methuselah lived one hundred and eighty-seven years and became the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Methuselah lived after the birth of Lamech seven hundred and eighty-two years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Methuselah were nine hundred and sixty-nine years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech lived one hundred and eighty-two years and had a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He named his son Noah, saying, “This one will comfort us concerning our work and the toil of our hands because of the ground which the Lord has cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech lived after the birth of Noah five hundred and ninety-five years and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the days of Lamech were seven hundred and seventy-seven years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was five hundred years old and became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When men began to multiply on the face of the earth and daughters were born to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sons of God saw that the daughters of men were fair and took as wives any they chose.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “My Spirit will not always strive with man, for he is flesh; yet his days will be a hundred and twenty years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days, and also after that, when the sons of God came in to the daughters of men, and they bore children to them. These were the mighty men who were of old, men of renown.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord saw that the wickedness of man was great on the earth, and that every intent of the thoughts of his heart was continually only evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was sorry that He had made man on the earth, and it grieved Him in His heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “I will destroy man, whom I have created, from the face of the earth—both man and beast, and the creeping things, and the birds of the sky, for I am sorry that I have made them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Noah found grace in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the generations of Noah.
Noah was a just man and blameless among his contemporaries. Noah walked with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth was corrupt before God and filled with violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: God looked on the earth and saw it was corrupt, for all flesh had corrupted their way on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God said to Noah, “The end of all flesh is come before Me, for the earth is filled with violence because of them. Now I will destroy them with the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make an ark of cypress wood for yourself. Make rooms in the ark, and cover it inside and out with pitch.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is how you must make it: The length of the ark will be three hundred cubits, the width of it fifty cubits, and the height of it thirty cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make an opening one cubit below the top of the ark all around; and you must set the door of the ark on the side. Make it with a lower, a second, and a third story.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring a flood of waters on the earth to destroy all flesh, wherever there is the breath of life under heaven, and everything that is on the earth will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will establish My covenant with you; you must go into the ark—you, and your sons, and your wife, and your sons’ wives with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring every living thing of all flesh, two of every kind, into the ark to keep them alive with you. They shall be male and female.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two of every kind of bird, of every kind of animal, and of every kind of creeping thing of the earth will come to you to be kept alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, take with you of every kind of food that is eaten and gather it to yourself, and it will be for food for you and for them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah did this; he did all that God commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Noah, “You and your entire household go into the ark, for you alone I have seen to be righteous before Me among this generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take with you seven each of every clean animal, the male and its female, and two each of every unclean animal, the male and its female,
speaker: Narrator

text: and seven each of birds of the air, the male and female, to keep offspring alive on the face of all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In seven days I will cause it to rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights, and every living thing that I have made I will destroy from the face of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Noah did according to all that the Lord commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was six hundred years old when the floodwaters came upon the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Noah went with his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives into the ark because of the floodwaters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything that creeps on the land from clean and unclean animals and birds
speaker: Narrator

text: came in two by two, male and female, to Noah into the ark, as God had commanded Noah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After seven days, the waters of the flood were on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, the same day, all the fountains of the great deep burst open and the floodgates of the heavens were opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rain fell upon the earth for forty days and forty nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the very same day Noah and the sons of Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth, and Noah’s wife, and the three wives of his sons with them, entered the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: They and every wild animal according to its kind, and all the livestock according to their kind, and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth according to its kind, and every bird according to its kind, every bird of every sort,
speaker: Narrator

text: went with Noah into the ark, two by two of all flesh in which was the breath of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went in, male and female of all flesh, just as God had commanded him; then the Lord shut him in.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood was on the earth forty days, and the water increased and lifted up the ark, so that it rose up above the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water prevailed and increased greatly upon the earth, and the ark floated on the surface of the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water prevailed exceedingly on the earth, and all the high mountains that were under the whole heaven were covered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters prevailed upward and the mountains were covered fifteen cubits deep.
speaker: Narrator

text: All flesh that moved on the earth died: birds and livestock and beasts, and every creeping thing that crept on the earth, and every man.
speaker: Narrator

text: All in whose nostrils was the breath of life, all that was on the dry land, died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So He blotted out every living thing which was on the face of the ground, both man and animals and the creeping things and the birds of the heavens. They were blotted out from the earth, and only Noah and those who were with him in the ark remained alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: The waters prevailed on the earth for one hundred and fifty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: God remembered Noah and every living thing and all the livestock that were with him in the ark. So God made a wind to pass over the earth, and the water receded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also the fountains of the deep and the floodgates of heaven were closed, and the rain from the heavens was restrained.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water receded steadily from the earth, and after the end of one hundred and fifty days the waters decreased.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ark rested in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, on the mountains of Ararat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water continually decreased until the tenth month. In the tenth month, on the first day of the month, the tops of the mountains became visible.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then at the end of forty days, Noah opened the window of the ark which he had made,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he sent forth a raven, which went to and fro until the waters were dried up on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent out a dove to see if the waters had subsided from the face of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the dove found no rest for the sole of her foot, so she returned to him into the ark, for the waters were on the surface of all the earth. Then he put forth his hand, and took her, and brought her into the ark to himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited yet another seven days, and again he sent out the dove from the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: The dove came to him in the evening, and in her mouth there was a freshly plucked olive leaf. So Noah knew that the waters had receded from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited another seven days and sent out the dove again, but it did not return to him again.
speaker: Narrator

text: So in the six hundred and first year, in the first month, the first day of the month, the waters were dried up from the earth; and Noah removed the covering of the ark, and looked, and saw the surface of the ground was dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God spoke to Noah, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go out of the ark, you and your wife, and your sons and your sons’ wives with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring out with you every living thing of all flesh that is with you, birds and animals, and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth, so that they may breed abundantly on the earth and be fruitful and multiply on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah and his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every beast, every creeping thing, every bird, and everything that moves on the earth, according to their families, went out of the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Noah built an altar to the Lord and took of every clean animal and of every clean bird and offered burnt offerings on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord smelled a soothing aroma; and the Lord said in His heart, “I will never again curse the ground because of man, for the inclination of man’s heart is evil from his youth, nor will I again destroy every living thing as I have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While the earth remains,
seedtime and harvest,
cold and heat,
summer and winter,
and day and night
will not cease.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God blessed Noah and his sons and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every beast of the earth and every bird of the sky and all that moves on the earth and all the fish of the sea will fear you and be terrified of you. They are given into your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every moving thing that lives will be food for you. I give you everything, just as I gave you the green plant.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Only you shall not eat flesh with its life, that is, its blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for your own lifeblood I will surely require a reckoning; from every animal will I require it; of man, too, will I require a reckoning for human life, of every man for that of his fellow man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever sheds the blood of man,
    by man shall his blood be shed;
for God made man
    in His own image.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for you, be fruitful and multiply; increase abundantly in the earth and multiply in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again God spoke to Noah and to his sons with him, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for Me, I establish My covenant with you, and with your descendants after you;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with every living creature that is with you, the birds, the livestock, and every beast of the earth with you; of all that comes out of the ark, every beast of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I establish My covenant with you. Never again shall all flesh be cut off by the waters of a flood. Never again shall there be a flood to destroy the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “This is the sign of the covenant which I am making between Me and you and every living creature that is with you, for all future generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have set My rainbow in the cloud, and it shall be a sign of a covenant between Me and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I bring a cloud over the earth, the rainbow will be seen in the cloud;
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will remember My covenant, which is between Me and you and every living creature of all flesh, and the waters will never again become a flood to destroy all flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rainbow will appear in the cloud, and I will see it and remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of all flesh that is on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God said to Noah, “This is the sign of the covenant that I have established between Me and all flesh that is on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Noah who went forth from the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Ham was the father of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the three sons of Noah, and from them the whole earth was populated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah began to be a man of the soil, and he planted a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he drank some of the wine and became drunk, and lay uncovered in his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ham, the father of Canaan, saw the nakedness of his father, and told his two brothers outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Shem and Japheth took a garment, and laid it upon both their shoulders, and went backward, and covered the nakedness of their father. Their faces were turned away, and they did not see their father’s nakedness.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Noah awoke from his wine and knew what his younger son had done to him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he said,
“Canaan be cursed!
    He will be a servant of servants
    to his brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also said,
“Blessed be the Lord God of Shem,
    and let Canaan be his servant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God enlarge Japheth,
    and may he dwell in the tents of Shem,
    and may Canaan be his servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah lived after the flood three hundred and fifty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the days of Noah were nine hundred and fifty years, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the generations of Shem, Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah. And sons were born to them after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Japheth were
Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshek, and Tiras.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Gomer were
Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Javan were
Elishah, Tarshish, the Kittites, and the Rodanites.
speaker: Narrator

text: From these the coastlands of the nations were divided into their lands, everyone according to his tongue, according to their families, by their nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Ham were
Cush, Egypt, Put, and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Cush were
Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteka;
and the sons of Raamah were
Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush was the father of Nimrod. He became a mighty one on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a mighty hunter before the Lord. Therefore it is said, “Even like Nimrod the mighty hunter before the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The beginning of his kingdom was Babel, Uruk, Akkad, and Kalneh in the land of Shinar.
speaker: Narrator

text: From that land he went to Assyria and built Nineveh, the city Rehoboth Ir, and Calah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Resen between Nineveh and Calah (that is the principal city).
speaker: Narrator

text:
Egypt was the father of
the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, Naphtuhites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pathrusites, Kasluhites (from whom came the Philistines), and Caphtorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canaan was the father of
Sidon his firstborn and Heth,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hivites, Arkites, Sinites,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arvadites, Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
Later the families of the Canaanites spread abroad.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border of the Canaanites was from Sidon toward Gerar to Gaza, and then to Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboyim, as far as Lasha.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Ham, according to their families, according to their languages, in their lands and in their nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Shem, who was the father of all the children of Eber, whose older brother was Japheth, were sons born also.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Shem were
Elam, Ashur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Aram were
Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshek.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arphaxad was the father of Shelah,
and Shelah was the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To Eber were born two sons.
The name of one was Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided; his brother’s name was Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joktan was the father of
Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their dwelling place was from Mesha all the way to Sephar, the hill country of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Shem, by their families and their language, in their lands and their nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the sons of Noah, according to their generations, in their nations. From these were the nations divided in the earth after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the whole earth had one language and the same words.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the people journeyed from the east, they found a plain in the land of Shinar and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to each other, “Let us make bricks and bake them thoroughly.” And they had brick for stone and tar for mortar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Come, let us build us a city and a tower, whose top will reach to heaven, and let us make a name for ourselves; otherwise we will be scattered abroad over the face of the whole earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord came down to see the city and the tower that the sons of men built.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “The people are one and they have one language, and this is only the beginning of what they will do; now nothing that they propose to do will be impossible for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us go down and there confuse their language, so that they may not understand one another’s speech.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord scattered them abroad from there over the face of all the earth, and they stopped building the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the name of it was called Babel, because there the Lord confused the language of all the earth. From there the Lord scattered them abroad over the face of all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the generations of Shem.
Shem was a hundred years old, and two years after the flood he became the father of Arphaxad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shem lived after the birth of Arphaxad five hundred years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arphaxad lived thirty-five years, and became the father of Shelah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arphaxad lived after the birth of Shelah four hundred and three years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelah lived thirty years, and became the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelah lived after the birth of Eber four hundred and three years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber lived thirty-four years, and became the father of Peleg.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber lived after the birth of Peleg four hundred and thirty years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peleg lived thirty years, and became the father of Reu.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peleg lived after the birth of Reu two hundred and nine years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reu lived thirty-two years, and became the father of Serug.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reu lived after the birth of Serug two hundred and seven years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Serug lived thirty years, and became the father of Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Serug lived after the birth of Nahor two hundred years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahor lived twenty-nine years, and became the father of Terah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahor lived after the birth of Terah one hundred and nineteen years, and had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Terah lived seventy years, and became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the generations of Terah.
Terah became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran, and Haran became the father of Lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Haran died before his father Terah in the land of his birth, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram and Nahor took wives. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife, Milkah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milkah and the father of Iskah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarai was barren; she had no child.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terah took his son Abram and his grandson Lot, son of Haran, and his daughter-in-law Sarai, his son Abram’s wife, and they went out together from Ur of the Chaldeans to go into the land of Canaan; but when they came to Harran, they settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The days of Terah were two hundred and five years, and Terah died in Harran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Abram, “Go from your country, your family, and your father’s house to the land that I will show you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make of you a great nation;
    I will bless you
and make your name great,
    so that you will be a blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bless them who bless you
    and curse him who curses you,
and in you all families of the earth
    will be blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram departed, as the Lord had spoken to him, and Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he departed from Harran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram took Sarai his wife, Lot his brother’s son, and all their possessions that they had accumulated, and the people that they had acquired in Harran, and they set out for the land of Canaan. They came to the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram passed through the land to the place of Shechem, to the oak of Moreh. The Canaanites were in the land at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to Abram and said, “To your descendants I will give this land.” So he built an altar to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there he continued on to a mountain to the east of Bethel and pitched his tent, having Bethel on the west and Ai on the east. There he built an altar to the Lord and called on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram continued his journey toward the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a famine in the land, so Abram went down to Egypt to live there, for the famine was severe in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was getting near to Egypt, he said to Sarai his wife, “I know you are a beautiful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, when the Egyptians see you, they will say, ‘This is his wife.’ They will then kill me, but they will let you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say you are my sister so that I may be treated well for your sake. Then my life will be spared because of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Abram entered Egypt, the Egyptians saw that Sarai was very beautiful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The princes of Pharaoh saw her and commended her to Pharaoh, and she was taken into Pharaoh’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He treated Abram well for her sake and he had sheep and livestock, male and female donkeys, male and female servants, and camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord afflicted Pharaoh and his house with great plagues because of Abram’s wife, Sarai.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh called Abram, and said, “What have you done to me? Why did you not tell me that she was your wife?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister’? I might have taken her as my wife. Now here is your wife; take her and leave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh commanded his men concerning him, and they sent him away with his wife and all that he had.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram went up from Egypt to the Negev, he and his wife and all that he had, and Lot with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram was very wealthy in livestock, in silver and in gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He continued on his journey from the Negev and came to Bethel, to the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Bethel and Ai,
speaker: Narrator

text: to the place where he first made an altar. There Abram called on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Lot, who went with Abram, also had flocks and herds and tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the land was not able to support them both dwelling together because their possessions were so great.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was strife between the herdsmen of Abram’s livestock and the herdsmen of Lot’s livestock. The Canaanites and the Perizzites dwelled in the land at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram said to Lot, “Let there be no strife, I ask you, between me and you, and between my herdsmen and your herdsmen, for we are close relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not the whole land before you? Please separate from me. If you will go to the left, then I will go to the right, or if you take the right, then I will go to the left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot lifted up his eyes, and looked at all the valley of the Jordan, that it was well watered everywhere like the garden of the Lord, like the land of Egypt as you go to Zoar. This was before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Lot chose for himself the entire valley of the Jordan and journeyed east, and the two of them separated from each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram dwelled in the land of Canaan, and Lot dwelled in the cities of the valley and pitched his tent as far as Sodom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the men of Sodom were exceedingly wicked and sinners against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Lot had departed from him, the Lord said to Abram, “Lift up now your eyes, and look from the place where you are, northward and southward and eastward and westward.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the land that you see I will give to you and to your descendants forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your descendants like the dust of the earth, so that if a man could number the dust of the earth, then your descendants could also be numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arise, and walk throughout the land across its length and its width, for I will give it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram moved his tent and came and settled by the oaks of Mamre, which are in Hebron, and built an altar to the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days that Amraphel was king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Kedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of Goyim,
speaker: Narrator

text: they made war with Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboyim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar).
speaker: Narrator

text: All these were joined together in the Valley of Siddim (that is, the Dead Sea).
speaker: Narrator

text: For twelve years they had served Kedorlaomer, but in the thirteenth year they rebelled.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourteenth year, Kedorlaomer and the kings who were with him came and defeated the Rephaites in Ashteroth Karnaim, the Zuzites in Ham, and the Emites in Shaveh Kiriathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Horites in their hill country of Seir, as far as El Paran, which is by the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they turned back and came to En Mishpat (that is, Kadesh) and conquered all the country of the Amalekites and also the Amorites who lived in Hazezon Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Sodom, the king of Gomorrah, the king of Admah, the king of Zeboyim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar) came out, and they joined together in battle in the Valley of Siddim
speaker: Narrator

text: against Kedorlaomer, the king of Elam, Tidal king of Goyim, Amraphel king of Shinar, and Arioch king of Ellasar—four kings against five.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Valley of Siddim was full of tar pits, and as the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, some fell in them, and the rest fled to the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took all the possessions of Sodom and Gomorrah, and all their provisions, and departed.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also took Lot, Abram’s brother’s son, who lived in Sodom, and his possessions, and went their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one who had escaped came and told Abram the Hebrew, who was living near the oaks of Mamre the Amorite, brother of Eshkol and Aner, and these were allies with Abram.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram heard that his relative was taken captive, he armed his three hundred and eighteen trained servants born in his own house, and pursued them as far as Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the night he divided his men to attack them and defeated them, and pursued them as far as Hobah, which is north of Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought back all the possessions, along with his relative Lot and his possessions, and also the women and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: After his return from the defeat of Kedorlaomer and the kings who had joined with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet him in the Valley of Shaveh (that is, the King’s Valley).
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine. He was the priest of God Most High.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
and blessed be God Most High,
    who has delivered your enemies into your hand.”
Then Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Sodom said to Abram, “Give me the people and take the goods for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I have lifted up my hand to the Lord, God Most High, the Possessor of heaven and earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I will take nothing that is yours, not a thread or a sandal strap; lest you say, ‘I have made Abram rich.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will accept only that which my men have eaten and the portion that belongs to the men who went with me, Aner, Eshkol, and Mamre. Let them take their portion.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
After this the word of the Lord came to Abram in a vision, saying,
“Do not fear, Abram.
    I am your shield,
    your exceedingly great reward.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said, “Lord God, what will You give me, seeing I am childless and the heir of my house is Eliezer of Damascus?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram said, “Since You have not given me any children, my heir is a servant born in my house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to him, saying, “This man will not be your heir, but a son that is from your own body will be your heir.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought him outside and said, “Look up toward heaven and count the stars, if you are able to count them.” And He said to him, “So will your descendants be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram believed the Lord, and He credited it to him as righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also said to him, “I am the Lord who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land to possess it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said, “Lord God, how may I know that I will possess it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So He said to him, “Bring Me a three-year-old heifer, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram brought all of these to Him and cut them in two and laid each piece opposite the other, but he did not cut the birds in half.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the birds of prey came down on the carcasses, Abram drove them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell on Abram, and terror and a great darkness fell on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He said to Abram, “Know for certain that your descendants will live as strangers in a land that is not theirs, and they will be enslaved and mistreated for four hundred years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will judge the nation that they serve, and afterward they will come out with great possessions.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, you will go to your fathers in peace and you will be buried at a good old age.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth generation, your descendants will return here, for the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet complete.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun went down and it was dark, a smoking fire pot with a flaming torch passed between these pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that same day the Lord made a covenant with Abram, saying, “To your descendants I have given this land, from the river of Egypt to the great Euphrates River—
speaker: Narrator

text: the land of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaites,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Sarai, Abram’s wife, had borne him no children, and she had a maidservant, an Egyptian, whose name was Hagar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Sarai said to Abram, “The Lord has prevented me from having children. Please go in to my maid; it may be that I will obtain children through her.”
Abram listened to Sarai.
speaker: Narrator

text: So after Abram had been living for ten years in the land of Canaan, Sarai, his wife, took Hagar her maid, the Egyptian, and gave her to her husband Abram to be his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He went in to Hagar, and she conceived.
When she saw that she had conceived, she began to despise her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sarai said to Abram, “May the wrong done to me be on you! I gave my maid into your arms; and when she saw that she had conceived, I became despised in her eyes. May the Lord judge between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said to Sarai, “Indeed, your maid is in your power; do to her as you please.” Then Sarai dealt harshly with her, and she fled from her presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord found her by a spring of water in the wilderness. It was the spring on the way to Shur.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said, “Hagar, Sarai’s maid, where have you come from and where are you going?”
And she said, “I am fleeing from the presence of my mistress Sarai.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord said to her, “Return to your mistress, and submit yourself to her authority.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord also said to her, “I will multiply your descendants exceedingly so that they will be too many to count.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the angel of the Lord said to her,
“You are pregnant
    and will bear a son.
You shall call his name Ishmael,
    because the Lord has heard your affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will be a wild man;
    his hand will be against every man,
    and every man’s hand will be against him.
And he will dwell
    in the presence of all his brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she called the name of the Lord that spoke to her, “You are the God who sees,” for she said, “Have I now looked on Him who sees me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the well was called Beer Lahai Roi. It is between Kadesh and Bered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hagar bore Abram a son, and Abram called the son she bore Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael to Abram.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the Lord appeared to him and said, “I am Almighty God. Walk before Me and be blameless.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will make My covenant between you and Me and will exceedingly multiply you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram fell on his face and God said to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for Me, My covenant is with you, and you shall be the father of a multitude of nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: No longer will your name be called Abram, but your name will be Abraham, for I have made you the father of a multitude of nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make you exceedingly fruitful; and I will make nations of you, and kings will come from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish My covenant between Me and you and your descendants after you throughout their generations for an everlasting covenant, to be God to you and your descendants after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the land of Canaan, where you now live as strangers, I will give to you and to your descendants for an everlasting possession, and I will be their God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Abraham, “As for you, you shall keep My covenant, you and your descendants after you throughout their generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is My covenant, which you shall keep, between Me and you and your descendants after you; every male among you shall be circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskins, and it shall be a sign of the covenant between Me and you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every male throughout every generation that is eight days old shall be circumcised, whether born in your household or bought with money from a foreigner who is not your descendant.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who is born in your house and he who is bought with your money must be circumcised. My covenant shall be in your flesh as an everlasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any uncircumcised male whose flesh of his foreskin is not circumcised shall be cut off from his people. He has broken My covenant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Abraham, “As for Sarai your wife, you will not call her name Sarai, but her name will be Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bless her and also give you a son by her. I will bless her, and she will be the mother of nations. Kings of peoples will come from her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham fell on his face and laughed and said in his heart, “Shall a child be born to a man that is a hundred years old? Shall Sarah, who is ninety years old, bear a child?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said to God, “Oh, that Ishmael might live before You!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “No, but your wife Sarah will bear you a son, and you will call his name Isaac. I will establish My covenant with him as an everlasting covenant and with his descendants after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for Ishmael, I have heard you. I have blessed him, and will make him fruitful and will multiply him exceedingly. He will be the father of twelve princes, and I will make him a great nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will establish My covenant with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you at this set time next year.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He stopped talking with Abraham, and God went up from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham took Ishmael, his son, and all that were born in his house, and all that were bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham’s household, and circumcised the flesh of their foreskins that very same day as God had said to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
speaker: Narrator

text: His son, Ishmael, was thirteen years old when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham and Ishmael were circumcised on the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men born in Abraham’s household or bought from foreigners were circumcised with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to Abraham near the great oak trees of Mamre while he sat in the tent door in the heat of the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham lifted up his eyes and looked and saw three men standing across from him. When he saw them, he ran from the tent door to meet them and bowed himself toward the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “My Lord, if I have found favor in Your sight, do not pass by Your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let a little water be brought and wash your feet and rest yourselves under the tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring a piece of bread so that you may refresh yourselves. After that you may pass on, now that you have come to your servant.”
And they said, “So do, as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham hurried into the tent to Sarah, and said, “Quickly prepare three measures of fine flour, knead it, and make cakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham ran to the herd and took a choice and tender calf and gave it to a servant, who hurried to prepare it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then brought butter and milk and the calf that he had prepared and set it before them; and he stood by them under the tree while they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to him, “Where is Sarah your wife?”
And he said, “There, in the tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
One of them said, “I will certainly return to you about this time next year, and Sarah your wife will have a son.”
And Sarah heard it in the tent door, which was behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham and Sarah were old and very advanced in age, and Sarah was well past childbearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Sarah laughed to herself, saying, “After I am so old and my lord is old also, shall I have pleasure?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh and say, ‘Shall I surely bear a child when I am old?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anything too difficult for the Lord? At the appointed time I will return to you, at this time next year, and Sarah will have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Sarah denied it, saying, “I did not laugh,” because she was afraid.
But He said, “Yes, you did laugh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men rose up and looked toward Sodom, and Abraham went with them to see them on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Should I hide from Abraham what I am doing,
speaker: Narrator

text: since Abraham will surely become a great and mighty nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed in him?
speaker: Narrator

text: I chose him, and he will instruct his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord by doing righteousness and justice, so that the Lord may bring to Abraham what He promised him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “Because the outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is great, and because their sin is very grave,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go down and see if what they have done is as bad as the outcry that has come to Me. If not, I will know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men turned away from there and went toward Sodom, but Abraham remained standing before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham drew near and said, “Shall You also destroy the righteous with the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text: What if there are fifty righteous in the city? Shall You also destroy, and not spare the place, for the fifty righteous who are in it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Far be it from You to do such a thing as this, to slay the righteous with the wicked, so that the righteous should be treated like the wicked; far be it from You. Should not the Judge of all the earth do right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, then I will spare the entire place for their sakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham answered and said, “I who am but dust and ashes have taken it upon myself to speak to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Suppose there were five less than the fifty righteous. Will You destroy all the city for lack of five?”
And He said, “If I find forty-five there, I will not destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he spoke to Him yet again and said, “Suppose there will be forty found there?”
So He said, “I will not do it for the sake of forty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said to Him, “Let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak. Suppose there will be thirty found there?”
Again He said, “I will not do it if I find thirty there.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Behold, I have undertaken to speak to the Lord. Suppose twenty are found there?”
He said, “I will not destroy it for the sake of twenty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said, “Let not the Lord be angry, and I will speak only once more. Suppose ten will be found there?”
Then He said, “I will not destroy it for the sake of ten.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord went His way as soon as He had stopped speaking to Abraham, and Abraham returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the two angels came to Sodom in the evening, and Lot was sitting at the gate of Sodom. When Lot saw them he rose up to meet them, and he bowed himself with his face toward the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said, “Here, my lords, please turn in to your servant’s house and spend the night and wash your feet; and then you may rise early and go on your way.”
They said, “No, we will stay in the open square all night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he strongly insisted, so they turned aside with him and entered his house. Then he made them a feast and baked unleavened bread, and they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before they lay down, the men of the city, the men of Sodom, both old and young, all the people from every quarter, surrounded the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They then called to Lot and said to him, “Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us, so that we may have relations with them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot went out through the door to them and shut the door behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Please, my brothers, do not act so wickedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I have two daughters who have not been with a man. Please, let me bring them out to you, and you may do to them as you wish. Only do nothing to these men, for they have come under the shelter of my roof.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they replied, “Stand back!” Also, they said, “This man came here as an alien, and he keeps acting like a judge. We will deal worse with you than with them.” So they pressed hard against Lot, and came close to breaking down the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men reached out their hands and pulled Lot into the house with them and shut the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they struck the men that were at the door of the house, both small and great, with blindness so that they wore themselves out groping for the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men said to Lot, “Have you anyone else here? Sons-in-law, sons, daughters, or anyone you have in the city, take them out of this place!
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are about to destroy this place, because the outcry against its people has grown great before the presence of the Lord, and the Lord has sent us to destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law, who had married his daughters, and said, “Get up, get out of this place, for the Lord will destroy this city!” But to his sons-in-law he seemed to be joking.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the morning dawned, the angels urged Lot, saying, “Arise, take your wife and your two daughters who are here. Otherwise you will be consumed in the punishment of the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And while he lingered, the men took hold of his and his wife’s hands, along with the hands of his two daughters, the Lord being merciful to him, and brought him out and set him outside the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had brought them out, one of them said to them, “Escape for your lives! Do not look behind you or stay anywhere in the plain. Escape to the mountain, lest you be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Lot said to them, “Please, no, my lords!
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant has found grace in your eyes, and you have shown your mercy, which you have shown to me by saving my life. However, I cannot escape to the mountain. Otherwise some evil will overtake me, and I will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, this city is close enough to flee to, and it is a little one. Please, let me escape there (is it not a little one?), and my life will be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “I have granted your request in this matter also. I will not overthrow this city of which you have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurry, escape there, for I cannot do anything until you arrive there.” Therefore the name of the city was called Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun had risen over the land when Lot entered Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord rained brimstone and fire on Sodom and Gomorrah. It was from the Lord out of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: So He overthrew those cities, all the valley, all the inhabitants of the cities, and what grew on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his wife, behind him, looked back, and she became a pillar of salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham got up early in the morning and went to the place where he stood before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he looked toward Sodom and Gomorrah, and toward all the land of the valley, and he saw the smoke of the land going up like the smoke of a furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it was that when God destroyed the cities of the valley, God remembered Abraham, and sent Lot out of the middle of the destruction, when He overthrew the cities in which Lot lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Lot left Zoar, and lived in the mountains, along with his two daughters who were with him, for he was afraid to dwell in Zoar. He and his two daughters lived in a cave.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the firstborn said to the younger, “Our father is old, and there is no man on the earth to have relations with us after the manner of all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us make our father drink wine and let us lie with him, so that we may preserve the lineage of our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made their father drink wine that night, and the firstborn went in and had relations with her father. He did not know when she lay down or when she arose.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day the firstborn said to the younger, “Indeed, last night I had relations with my father. Let us make him drink wine tonight also, so that you may go in and have relations with him, so that we may preserve the lineage of our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made their father drink wine that night also. Then the younger arose and lay down with him, and he did not know when she lay down or when she arose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore both the daughters of Lot were pregnant by their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: The firstborn bore a son and called his name Moab. He is the father of the Moabites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The younger also gave birth to a son and called his name Ben-Ammi. He is the father of the Ammonites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham journeyed from there toward the Negev, settled between Kadesh and Shur, and then he sojourned in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham said about Sarah his wife, “She is my sister.” So Abimelek, king of Gerar, sent for her and took Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God came to Abimelek in a dream by night and said to him, “You are a dead man because of the woman whom you have taken, for she is a man’s wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek had not gone near her, and he said, “Lord, will You slay a righteous nation?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did he not say to me, ‘She is my sister,’ and did not even she herself say, ‘He is my brother’? In the integrity of my heart and innocence of my hands I have done this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And God said to him in a dream, “Yes, I know that you did this in the integrity of your heart. For I also kept you from sinning against Me. Therefore, I did not let you touch her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore return the man’s wife, for he is a prophet and he will pray for you. Moreover, you will live. However, if you do not return her, know that you will surely die, you and all who are yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelek rose early in the morning, and called all his servants and told them all these things, and the men were very afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelek called Abraham and said to him, “What have you done to us? How have I offended you that you would bring on me and on my kingdom a great sin? You have done things to me that should not have been done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelek said to Abraham, “What were you thinking of, that you did this thing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “Because I thought, surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will slay me because of my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still, indeed, she is my sister. She is the daughter of my father, but not the daughter of my mother. She became my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When God caused me to travel from my father’s house, I said to her, ‘This is your kindness which you must show me: Every place where we go, say concerning me, He is my brother.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelek took sheep, oxen, and male and female servants, and gave them to Abraham, and returned his wife Sarah to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek said, “My land is before you; settle wherever it pleases you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: To Sarah he said, “I have given your brother a thousand shekels of silver. It is a sign of your innocence in the eyes of all who are with you, and before everyone you are vindicated.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelek, his wife, and his female servants. Then they bore children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had closed up all the wombs of the house of Abimelek because of Sarah, Abraham’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord visited Sarah as He had said, and the Lord did for Sarah as He had spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Sarah conceived and bore Abraham a son in his old age, at the set time that God had spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham called the name of his son who was born to him, whom Sarah bore to him, Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old, as God had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Sarah said, “God has made me laugh. All who hear will laugh with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Also she said, “Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the child grew and was weaned. Then Abraham made a great feast the same day that Isaac was weaned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian, whom she had borne to Abraham, mocking.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore she said to Abraham, “Throw out this slave woman and her son, for the son of this slave woman shall not be heir with my son, Isaac.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This matter was very displeasing in Abraham’s sight because of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God said to Abraham, “Do not be upset concerning the boy and your slave wife. Whatever Sarah has said to you, listen to what she says, for in Isaac your descendants will be called.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I will also make a nation of the son of the slave woman, because he is your offspring.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham rose up early in the morning, and took bread and a skin of water and gave it to Hagar, putting it on her shoulder, and sent her away with the child. So she departed and wandered in the Wilderness of Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the water in the skin was gone, she placed the child under one of the shrubs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she went and sat down across from him at a distance of about a bowshot, for she said to herself, “Let me not see the death of the child.” She sat across from him, and lifted up her voice and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God heard the boy’s voice. Then the angel of God called to Hagar out of heaven and said to her, “What is the matter with you, Hagar? Do not be afraid, for God has heard the voice of the boy where he is.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arise, pick up the boy and hold him in your hands, for I will make him a great nation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of water. And she went and filled the skin with water and gave the boy a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: God was with the boy; and he grew and lived in the wilderness and became an archer.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived in the Wilderness of Paran, and his mother found a wife for him out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it came to pass at that time that Abimelek and Phicol, the commander of his army, spoke to Abraham, saying, “God is with you in all that you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, swear to me by God that you will not deal deceitfully with me, or with my children, or with my descendants. Instead, according to the kindness that I have shown to you, you will show to me and to the land where you have lived.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “I will swear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham complained to Abimelek about a well of water that Abimelek’s servants had violently seized.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abimelek said, “I do not know who has done this. You did not tell me, and I have not heard of it until today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham took sheep and oxen and gave them to Abimelek, and the two of them made a covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham set seven ewe lambs of the flock by themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abimelek said to Abraham, “What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs that you have set by themselves?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “You shall take these seven ewe lambs from my hand so that they may be a witness that I have dug this well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore he called that place Beersheba, because the two of them swore an oath there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus they made a covenant at Beersheba. Then Abimelek rose with Phicol, the commander of his army, and they returned to the land of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beersheba, and there he called on the name of the Lord, the Everlasting God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham stayed in the land of the Philistines many days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After these things God tested Abraham and said to him, “Abraham!”
And he said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He said, “Take your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the land of Moriah, and offer him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains of which I will tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham rose up early in the morning and saddled his donkey, and took two of his young men with him and Isaac his son; and he split the wood for the burnt offering, and arose and went to the place that God had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then on the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes and saw the place from a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said to his young men, “Stay here with the donkey. The boy and I will go over there and worship and then return to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham took the wood of the burnt offering and laid it on Isaac his son; and he took the fire in his hand and the knife. So the two of them walked on together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Isaac spoke to Abraham his father and said, “My father!”
And he said, “Here I am, my son.”
Then he said, “Here is the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “My son, God will provide for Himself the lamb for a burnt offering.” So the two of them went together.
speaker: Narrator
