text: Then they came to the place that God had told him. So Abraham built an altar there and arranged the wood; and he bound Isaac his son and laid him on the altar, on the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham stretched out his hand and took the knife to slay his son.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the angel of the Lord called to him out of heaven and said, “Abraham, Abraham!”
And he said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He said, “Do not lay your hands on the boy or do anything to him, because now I know that you fear God, seeing you have not withheld your only son from Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham lifted up his eyes and looked, and behind him was a ram caught in a thicket by his horns. So Abraham went and took the ram and offered him up as a burnt offering in the place of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham called the name of that place The Lord Will Provide, as it is said to this day, “In the mount of the Lord it will be provided.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord called to Abraham out of heaven a second time,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “By Myself I have sworn, says the Lord, because you have done this thing, and have not withheld your son, your only son,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will indeed bless you and I will indeed multiply your descendants as the stars of the heavens and as the sand that is on the seashore. Your descendants will possess the gate of their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through your offspring all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed My voice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham returned to his young men, and they arose and went together to Beersheba. Then Abraham lived at Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: After these things Abraham was told, “Milkah has also borne children to your brother Nahor:
speaker: Narrator

text: Uz his firstborn, Buz his brother, Kemuel the father of Aram,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. Milkah gave birth to these eight to Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maakah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah lived one hundred and twenty-seven years. These were the years of the life of Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sarah died in Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan, and Abraham went in to mourn for Sarah and to weep for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham stood up from before his dead and spoke to the Hittites, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am a stranger and a foreigner among you. Give me property for a burying place among you, that I may bury my dead out of my sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Hittites answered Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Hear us, my lord. You are a mighty prince among us. Bury your dead in the choicest of our burial places. None of us will withhold from you his burial place that you may bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham stood up and bowed himself to the people of the land, the Hittites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke with them, saying, “If it be your wish that I bury my dead out of my sight, hear me and entreat Ephron the son of Zohar for me,
speaker: Narrator

text: that he may give me the cave of Machpelah, which he owns, at the end of his field. Let him give it to me in your presence for the full price for a burial site.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ephron was sitting among the Hittites; and Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the presence of all the Hittites, all who went in at the gate of his city, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, my lord. Hear me: I give you the field and the cave that is in it. I give it to you in the presence of the sons of my people. Bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham bowed before the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he spoke to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land, saying, “Indeed, if you will give it, please hear me. I will give you money for the field; take it from me and I will bury my dead there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ephron answered Abraham, saying to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “My lord, listen to me. The land is worth four hundred shekels of silver. What is that between me and you? So bury your dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham listened to Ephron; and Abraham weighed out for Ephron four hundred shekels of silver, the price that he had named in the hearing of the Hittites, according to the standard commercial measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the field of Ephron, which was in Machpelah, which was before Mamre, the field and the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were in the field that were within all the surrounding borders were deeded
speaker: Narrator

text: to Abraham as a possession in the presence of the Hittites, before all who went in at the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the cave of the field of Machpelah before Mamre (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the field and the cave that was in it were deeded to Abraham by the Hittites as property for a burial place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham was old, well advanced in age; and the Lord had blessed Abraham in all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham said to his servant, the oldest of his household, who was in charge over all that he had, “Please, place your hand under my thigh,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will make you swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of the earth, that you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you shall go to my country and to my family, and take a wife for my son Isaac.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant said to him, “Perhaps the woman will not be willing to follow me to this land. Must I take your son back to the land from which you came?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said to him, “See to it that you do not take my son back there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God of heaven, who took me from my father’s family and from the land of my relatives, and who spoke to me and swore to me, saying, ‘To your descendants I will give this land,’ He shall send His angel before you and you shall take a wife for my son from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the woman is not willing to follow you, then you will be free from my oath. Only do not take my son back there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant took ten of his master’s camels and departed, for all the goods of his master were in his hand. And he arose and went to the city of Nahor in Aram Naharaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made his camels kneel down outside the city by a well of water in the evening when the women came out to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “O Lord, the God of my master Abraham, please let me have success this day and show kindness to my master Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, here I stand by the well of water, and the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to draw water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let it be that the young woman to whom I shall say, ‘Please lower your pitcher, that I may drink,’ and she shall say, ‘Drink, and I will give your camels water also’—let her be the one that You have appointed for Your servant Isaac. Then I will know that You have shown kindness to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Before he had finished speaking, Rebekah, who was born to Bethuel, son of Milkah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother, came out with a pitcher on her shoulder.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young woman was very beautiful to look at, a virgin, and no man had ever been with her. She went down to the well and filled her pitcher and came up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant ran to meet her and said, “Please let me drink a little water from your pitcher.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she said, “Drink, my lord.” Then she quickly let down her pitcher to her hand and gave him a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, “I will draw water for your camels also, until they have finished drinking.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she quickly emptied her pitcher into the trough and ran to the well to draw water and drew for all his camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man, gazing at her, remained silent, trying to discern whether the Lord had made his journey a success or not.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took a gold nose ring of half a shekel weight and two bracelets for her wrists of ten shekels weight in gold,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “Whose daughter are you? Please tell me, is there room in your father’s house for us to lodge?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milkah, whom she bore to Nahor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again she said to him, “We have both straw and provision enough, and room in which to lodge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man bowed down his head and worshipped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Blessed be the Lord God of my master Abraham, who has not forsaken His mercy and His truth toward my master. As for me, the Lord led me to the house of my master’s relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young woman ran and told her mother’s household of these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban, and Laban ran out to the man at the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw the nose ring and bracelets on his sister’s hands and when he heard the words of Rebekah his sister, saying, “This is what the man said to me,” he went to the man who stood by the camels at the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Come in, blessed of the Lord. Why do you stand outside? I have prepared the house and a place for the camels.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man came to the house. Then he unloaded his camels and gave straw and provision to the camels and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He then set food before him to eat, but he said, “I will not eat until I have told about my errand.”
And he said, “Speak on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said, “I am Abraham’s servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has greatly blessed my master, and he has become wealthy. He has given him flocks and herds, and silver and gold, and male and female servants, and camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah my master’s wife bore a son to my master when she was old, and he has given to him all that he has.
speaker: Narrator

text: My master made me swear, saying, ‘You must not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you shall go to my father’s house, and to my relatives, and take a wife for my son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I said to my master, ‘Perhaps the woman will not follow me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he said to me, ‘The Lord, before whom I walk, will send His angel with you and prosper your way, and you will take a wife for my son from my relatives and from my father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be free from my oath, when you come to my family, if they will not give her to you; then you will be released from my oath.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So today I came to the well and said, ‘O Lord, the God of my master Abraham, if You will now give me success in my task;
speaker: Narrator

text: I am standing by the well of water, and let it be that when the virgin comes forth to draw water, and I say to her, “Please give me a little water from your pitcher to drink,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and she says to me, “Drink, and I will also draw for your camels,” let her be the woman whom the Lord has appointed for my master’s son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Before I had finished speaking in my heart, there was Rebekah coming out with her pitcher on her shoulder; and she went down to the well and drew water. Then I said to her, ‘Please let me drink.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “She then quickly let down her pitcher from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I will give your camels a drink also.’ So I drank, and she gave the camels a drink also.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’
“And she said, ‘The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor’s son, whom Milkah bore for him.’
“So I put the nose ring on her nose and the bracelets on her wrists.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I bowed down my head and worshipped the Lord, and blessed the Lord God of my master Abraham, who had led me in the right way to take the daughter of my master’s brother for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now if you will deal kindly and truly with my master, tell me; and if not, tell me, so that I may turn to the right hand or to the left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban and Bethuel answered and said, “This thing comes from the Lord; we cannot speak to you bad or good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is Rebekah before you; take her and go, and let her be the wife of your master’s son, as the Lord has spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abraham’s servant heard their words, he worshipped the Lord, bowing himself to the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant brought out jewels of silver and gold, and clothing and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave precious things to her brother and to her mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they ate and drank, he and the men who were with him, and stayed all night.
The next morning they arose, and he said, “Send me away to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But her brother and her mother said, “Let the young woman remain with us a few days, at least ten; after that she may go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to them, “Do not delay me, seeing the Lord has given me success. Let me go that I may go to my master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We will call the girl and ask her.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they called Rebekah and said to her, “Will you go with this man?”
And she said, “I will go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent away Rebekah their sister and her nurse, and Abraham’s servant and his men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They blessed Rebekah and said to her,
“May you, our sister, become the mother
    of thousands of ten thousands;
and may your descendants possess
    the gate of those who hate them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah and her maids arose and they rode on the camels and followed the man. So the servant took Rebekah and went his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Isaac came from the way of Beer Lahai Roi, for he lived in the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac went out in the evening to meditate in the field; and he lifted up his eyes and looked, and surely the camels were coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rebekah lifted up her eyes, and when she saw Isaac, she dismounted from her camel
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said to the servant, “Who is this man walking in the field to meet us?”
The servant said, “It is my master.” Therefore she took a veil and covered herself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant told Isaac all the things he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac brought her into the tent of his mother Sarah; and he took Rebekah and she became his wife and he loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham took another wife, whose name was Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she bore to him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan. The descendants of Dedan were the Ashurites, the Letushites, and the Leummites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanok, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the children of Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave all that he had to Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the sons of his concubines Abraham gave gifts, and while he was still living, he sent them away from his son Isaac eastward to the east country.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the years of Abraham’s life that he lived: one hundred and seventy-five years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham breathed his last and died at a good old age, an old man and full of years; and he was gathered to his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron the son of Zohar the Hittite, east of Mamre,
speaker: Narrator

text: the field that Abraham purchased from the sons of Heth. There Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the death of Abraham, God blessed his son Isaac. Isaac lived at Beer Lahai Roi.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the generations of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s maidservant, bore to Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the sons of Ishmael, by their names, according to their generations: the firstborn of Ishmael, Nebaioth, and then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Ishmael, and these were their names, by their towns and their settlements, twelve princes according to their peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the years of the life of Ishmael: one hundred and thirty-seven years. He breathed his last and died; and he was gathered to his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They lived from Havilah as far as Shur, which is east of Egypt, as you go toward Assyria. He died in the presence of all his relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the generations of Isaac, Abraham’s son.
Abraham was the father of Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac was forty years old when he took Rebekah as his wife, the daughter of Bethuel the Syrian of Paddan Aram, the sister to Laban the Syrian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Isaac pleaded with the Lord for his wife, because she was barren; and the Lord granted his plea, and Rebekah his wife conceived.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the children struggled together within her, and she said, “If all is well, why am I like this?” So she went to inquire of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord said to her,
“Two nations are in your womb,
    and two peoples will be separated from your body;
one people will be stronger than the other,
    and the older will serve the younger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the time of her delivery came, there were twins in her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first came out red all over, like a hairy garment, and they called his name Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that his brother came out, and his hand took hold of Esau’s heel, so he was named Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when she bore them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the boys grew. Esau was a cunning hunter, a man of the field, while Jacob was a calm man, living in tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac loved Esau, because he ate of his game, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob cooked a stew; and Esau came in from the field and he was famished.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau said to Jacob, “Please feed me some of that red stew, for I am famished.” Therefore his name was called Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said, “First sell me your birthright.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “Look, I am about to die; of what use is the birthright to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said, “Swear to me this day.” So he swore to him, and he sold his birthright to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jacob gave Esau bread and lentil stew. Then he ate and drank, arose, and went his way.
Thus Esau despised his birthright.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a famine in the land, in addition to the first famine that was during the days of Abraham. Isaac went to Abimelek king of the Philistines in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to him and said, “Do not go down to Egypt. Live in the land of which I will tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sojourn in this land, and I will be with you and will bless you; for I will give to you and all your descendants all these lands, and I will fulfill the oath which I swore to Abraham your father.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your descendants multiply as the stars of the heavens and will give your descendants all these lands. By your descendants all the nations of the earth will be blessed,
speaker: Narrator

text: because Abraham obeyed Me and kept My charge, My commandments, My statutes, and My laws.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac lived in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of the place asked him about his wife. And he said, “She is my sister,” for he was afraid to say, “She is my wife,” thinking, “The men of the place might kill me on account of Rebekah, because she is beautiful in appearance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had been there a long time, Abimelek the king of the Philistines looked out of a window and saw Isaac caressing Rebekah his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abimelek summoned Isaac and said, “She is surely your wife, so how is it you said, ‘She is my sister’?”
Then Isaac said to him, “Because I said, ‘I might die on account of her.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek said, “What is this you have done to us? One of the people might have easily lain with your wife, and you might have brought guilt upon us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek charged all his people, saying, “He who touches this man or his wife will surely be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac sowed in that land and reaped in the same year a hundredfold; the Lord blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man became rich and continued to prosper until he became very wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he had possessions of flocks and herds and a great number of servants so that the Philistines envied him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Philistines had stopped up all the wells which his father’s servants had dug in the days of Abraham his father by filling them with dirt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelek said to Isaac, “Go away from us, for you are much more powerful than we are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac departed from there and pitched his tent in the Valley of Gerar and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac dug again the wells of water, which they had dug in the days of Abraham his father, for the Philistines had stopped them up after the death of Abraham. He called their names after the names his father had called them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Isaac’s servants dug in the valley and found a well of running water there,
speaker: Narrator

text: the herdsmen of Gerar contended with Isaac’s herdsmen, saying, “The water is ours.” So he called the name of the well Esek, because they contended with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They dug another well and quarreled over that also. So he called the name of it Sitnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he moved away from there and dug another well, and they did not quarrel over it. So he called the name of it Rehoboth, for he said, “For now the Lord has made room for us, and we will be fruitful in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up from there to Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to him that same night and said, “I am the God of Abraham your father. Do not fear, for I am with you. I will bless you and multiply your descendants for the sake of My servant Abraham.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He built an altar there, called on the name of the Lord, and pitched his tent there. And there Isaac’s servants dug a well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelek went to him from Gerar, along with Ahuzzath, one of his friends, and Phicol the commander of his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said to them, “Why have you come to me, since you hate me and have sent me away from you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “We saw plainly that the Lord was with you. So we said, ‘Let there now be an oath between us, between you and us, and let us make a covenant with you,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you will do us no harm, just as we have not touched you, and have done you nothing but good and have sent you away in peace. You are now the blessed of the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he made them a feast, and they ate and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: They rose up early in the morning and swore an oath with one another. Isaac sent them away, and they departed from him in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well that they had dug and said to him, “We have found water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he called it Shibah. Therefore, the name of the city is Beersheba to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau was forty years old when he took as wives Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they brought grief to Isaac and to Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Isaac was old and his eyes were so weak that he could not see, he called Esau his oldest son and said to him, “My son.”
And he answered him, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “I am old. I do not know the day of my death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, please take your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the field and hunt game for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And prepare for me savory food, such as I love, and bring it to me that I may eat, so that my soul may bless you before I die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah was listening when Isaac spoke to Esau his son. So when Esau went to the field to hunt for wild game and bring it back,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah said to her son Jacob, “I heard your father speak to your brother Esau, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Bring me wild game, and prepare for me savory food, that I may eat and bless you in the presence of the Lord before my death.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, my son, listen to me as I command you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go now to the flock, and get me two choice young goats, so that I may prepare from them savory food for your father, such as he loves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will take it to your father, so that he may eat and so that he may bless you before his death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, “Look, my brother Esau is a hairy man, and I am a man of smooth skin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps my father will feel me, and I will seem to him as a deceiver, and I will bring a curse on myself and not a blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His mother said to him, “Let your curse be upon me, my son. Only listen to me and go get them for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went and got them and brought them to his mother. Then his mother prepared savory food such as his father loved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah took the best clothes belonging to her older son Esau, which were with her in the house, and put them on Jacob her younger son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she put the skins of the young goats on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: She put the savory food and the bread, which she had prepared, into the hands of her son Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He came to his father and said, “My father.”
And he said, “Here I am. Who are you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn. I have done just as you asked me. Please arise, sit and eat of my wild game, so that your soul may bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isaac said to his son, “How is it that you have found it so quickly, my son?”
And he said, “Because the Lord your God brought it to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said to Jacob, “Please come near, so that I may feel you, my son, whether you are really my son Esau or not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob went near to his father Isaac, and he felt him and said, “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not recognize him because his hands were hairy, just like his brother Esau’s hands; so he blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked, “Are you really my son Esau?”
And he said, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Bring it near to me, and I will eat of my son’s wild game, so that my soul may bless you.”
And he brought it near to him, and he ate. He also brought him wine, and he drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father Isaac said to him, “Come near now and kiss me, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He came near and kissed him; and he smelled the smell of his clothing and blessed him and said,
“See, the smell of my son
    is like the smell of the field
    which the Lord has blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, may God give you of the dew of heaven
    and the fatness of the earth,
    and plenty of grain and new wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let peoples serve you,
    and nations bow down to you.
Be master over your brothers,
    and let your mother’s sons bow down to you.
Cursed be everyone who curses you,
    and blessed be those who bless you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had barely gone out from the presence of his father Isaac, Esau his brother came in from his hunting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also had prepared savory food and brought it to his father, and said to his father, “Let my father arise and eat of his son’s wild game, so that your soul may bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isaac his father said to him, “Who are you?”
And he said, “I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac trembled violently, and said, “Who? Where then is he who hunted game and brought it to me? I ate all of it before you came, and I have blessed him. Yes, and he shall be blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau heard the words of his father, he cried with a great and exceedingly bitter cry, and said to his father, “Bless me, even me also, O my father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Your brother came deceitfully and has taken away your blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has supplanted me these two times. He took away my birthright, and now he has taken away my blessing.” And he said, “Have you not reserved a blessing for me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac answered and said to Esau, “I have made him your lord, and I have given to him all his brothers as servants; and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. What can I now do for you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Esau said to his father, “Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me, even me also, O my father!” Then Esau lifted up his voice and wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isaac his father answered and said to him,
“Your dwelling shall be
    away from the fatness of the earth
    and away from the dew of heaven from above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will live by your sword
    and will serve your brother.
When you become restless,
    you will break his yoke
    from your neck.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father blessed him. And Esau said in his heart, “The days of mourning for my father are at hand; then I will kill my brother Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These words of Esau her older son were told to Rebekah; and she sent and called Jacob her younger son, and said to him, “Your brother Esau consoles himself regarding you by planning to kill you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, my son, listen to me and get up and flee to Laban, my brother in Harran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay with him a few days until your brother’s fury subsides,
speaker: Narrator

text: until your brother’s anger against you turns away, and he forgets what you have done to him. Then I will send and get you from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am tired of my life because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob takes a wife from the daughters of Heth, such as these who are of the daughters of the land, what good will my life be to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac called Jacob and blessed him. Then he charged him and said to him, “You must not take a wife of the daughters of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arise, go to Paddan Aram to the house of Bethuel your mother’s father, and take for yourself a wife from there, from the daughters of Laban your mother’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God Almighty bless you and make you fruitful and multiply you, so that you may become a multitude of people.
speaker: Narrator

text: May He give you the blessing of Abraham, to you and your descendants with you, that you may inherit the land where you are a stranger, which God gave to Abraham.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac sent Jacob away, and he went to Paddan Aram to Laban, the son of Bethuel the Syrian, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob’s and Esau’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him away to Paddan Aram to take for himself a wife from there, and that as he blessed him he gave him a charge, saying, “You must not take a wife of the daughters of Canaan,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and that Jacob obeyed his father and his mother and had gone to Paddan Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau saw that the daughters of Canaan did not please Isaac his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau went to Ishmael and took as his wife Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, the sister of Nebaioth, in addition to the wives he had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob went out from Beersheba and went toward Harran.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to a certain place and stayed there all night, because the sun had set. He took one of the stones of that place and put it under his head, and lay down in that place to sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: He dreamed and saw a ladder set up on the earth with the top of it reaching to heaven. The angels of God were ascending and descending on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord stood above it and said, “I am the Lord God of Abraham your father and the God of Isaac. The land on which you lie, to you will I give it and to your descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread abroad to the west and to the east and to the north and to the south, and in you and in your descendants all the families of the earth will be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, I am with you, and I will protect you wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. For I will not leave you until I have done what I promised you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob awoke out of his sleep, and he said, “Surely the Lord is in this place, and I did not know it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He was afraid and said, “How awesome is this place! This is none other but the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob rose up early in the morning and took the stone that he had put under his head, set it up as a pillar, and poured oil on top of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called the name of that place Bethel, but previously the name of the city was called Luz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob vowed a vow, saying, “If God will be with me and will protect me in this way that I go, and will give me bread to eat and clothing to put on,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that I return to my father’s house in peace, then the Lord will be my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then this stone, which I have set for a pillar, will be the house of God, and from all that You give me I will surely give a tenth to You.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob went on his journey and came into the land of the people of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he looked, he saw a well in the field and three flocks of sheep lying by it, for out of that well the flocks were watered. A large stone was on the well’s opening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the flocks were gathered there, the shepherds rolled the stone from the well’s opening, watered the sheep, then put the stone back on the well’s opening in its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jacob said to them, “My brothers, where are you from?”
And they said, “We are from Harran.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said to them, “Do you know Laban the son of Nahor?”
And they said, “We know him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to them, “Is he well?”
And they said, “He is well, and here is Rachel his daughter coming with the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Since it is yet midday, it is not the time that the livestock should be gathered together. Water the sheep, and go and feed them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We cannot until all the flocks are gathered together and the stone is rolled from the well’s opening. Then we may water the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking with them, Rachel came with her father’s sheep, for she kept them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob saw Rachel the daughter of Laban his mother’s brother and the sheep of Laban his mother’s brother, Jacob went near and rolled the stone from the well’s opening and watered the flock of Laban his mother’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob kissed Rachel and wept aloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob told Rachel that he was her father’s relative and that he was Rebekah’s son. Then she ran and told her father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Laban heard the news of Jacob his sister’s son, he ran to meet him and embraced him and kissed him and brought him to his house. Then Jacob told Laban all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Laban said to him, “Surely you are my bone and my flesh.”
And he stayed with him for a month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to Jacob, “Since you are my relative, should you therefore serve me for nothing? Tell me, what shall your wages be?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Laban had two daughters. The name of the older was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah’s eyes were tender, but Rachel was beautiful in form and appearance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob loved Rachel, so he said, “I will serve you seven years for Rachel your younger daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “It is better that I give her to you than that I should give her to another man. Stay with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob served seven years for Rachel, and they seemed to him but a few days because of the love he had for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife, for my days are fulfilled, so that I may have relations with her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban gathered together all the men of the place and prepared a feast.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the evening he took Leah his daughter and brought her to Jacob, and Jacob had relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban gave Zilpah his maid to his daughter Leah for a maidservant.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning Jacob discovered it was Leah, and he said to Laban, “What is this you have done to me? Did I not serve you for Rachel? Why then have you tricked me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban said, “It is not the custom in our country to marry off the younger before the firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fulfill the period of seven days for this one, and we will give you the other also in return for serving me another seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob did so and completed her week. Then Laban gave him Rachel his daughter as his wife also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban gave Bilhah his maidservant to Rachel his daughter to be her maid.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob also had relations with Rachel, and he loved Rachel more than Leah and served Laban another seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that Leah was unloved, He opened her womb, but Rachel was barren.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah conceived and gave birth to a son, and she called his name Reuben, for she said, “Surely the Lord has looked upon my affliction. Now therefore my husband will love me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived again and gave birth to a son and said, “Because the Lord has heard that I was unloved, He has therefore given me this son also.” Then she called his name Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived again and gave birth to a son and said, “Now this time my husband will be joined to me, because I have borne him three sons.” Therefore his name was called Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived again and gave birth to a son, and she said, “Now I will praise the Lord!” Therefore she called his name Judah. Then she stopped giving birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rachel saw that she could not give Jacob children, she became jealous of her sister. She said to Jacob, “Give me children, or I will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob became angry with Rachel and said, “Am I in the place of God, who has withheld from you the fruit of the womb?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “Here is my maid Bilhah. Have relations with her so that she may bear a child on my knees, so that I may also have children through her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she gave him Bilhah her maidservant as a wife, and Jacob had relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah conceived and gave Jacob a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel said, “God has vindicated me, and He has also heard my voice and has given me a son.” Therefore she called his name Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah, Rachel’s maid, conceived again and gave Jacob a second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel said, “With great wrestling have I wrestled with my sister, and I have prevailed.” So she called his name Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took Zilpah her maid and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zilpah, Leah’s maid, gave Jacob a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “How fortunate!” So she called his name Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zilpah, Leah’s maid, gave Jacob a second son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “Happy am I, for women will call me happy.” So she called his name Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time of the wheat harvest, Reuben went and found mandrakes in the field and brought them to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Leah said to her, “Is it a small matter that you have taken my husband? Would you take away my son’s mandrakes also?”
So Rachel said, “All right, he may lie with you tonight in exchange for your son’s mandrakes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob came out of the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him and said, “You must sleep with me, because I have paid for you with my son’s mandrakes.” And he slept with her that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: God listened to Leah, and she conceived and gave Jacob a fifth son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah said, “God has given me my reward because I have given my maid to my husband.” So she called his name Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah conceived again and gave Jacob a sixth son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah said, “God has given me a good gift. Now my husband will dwell with me, because I have given him six sons.” So she called his name Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards she gave birth to a daughter and called her name Dinah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God remembered Rachel, and God listened to her and opened her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived and gave birth to a son and said, “God has taken away my reproach.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she called his name Joseph, saying, “The Lord will add to me another son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me away, so that I may go to my own place, to my country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give me my wives and my children, for whom I have served you, and let me go. For you know the service that I have given you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to him, “If I have found favor in your eyes, please stay. For I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me on account of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Name me your wages, and I will give it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to him, “You know how I have served you, and how your livestock have fared with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you had little before I came, and it is now increased to a multitude. The Lord has blessed you since I came, and now when may I also provide for my own house?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Laban said, “What may I give you?”
And Jacob said, “You may not give me anything, but if you will do this one thing for me, I will continue to feed and keep your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will pass through all your flock today, removing from it all the speckled and spotted sheep, and every brown sheep from among the lambs, and the spotted and speckled among the goats. These shall be my wages.
speaker: Narrator

text: So my integrity will answer for me in time to come. When you come to examine my wages, every one that is not speckled and spotted among the goats, and brown among the sheep that are with me will be considered stolen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “Agreed. Let it be according to your word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed that day the male goats that were striped and spotted and all the female goats that were speckled and spotted, every one that had some white in it, and all the brown ones among the sheep, and gave them into the care of his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put three days’ journey between himself and Jacob, and Jacob fed the rest of Laban’s flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob took rods of fresh-cut poplar, almond, and plane trees, and peeled white streaks in them, exposing the white which was in the rods.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set the rods which he had peeled before the flocks in the troughs, that is, the watering places, where the flocks came to drink, so that they would mate when they came to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flocks mated before the rods and gave birth to young that were striped, speckled, and spotted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob separated the lambs and made the flocks face toward the striped and all the brown in the flock of Laban. He put his own flocks by themselves and did not put them with Laban’s sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the stronger sheep mated, Jacob laid the rods before the eyes of the sheep in the troughs, so that they might mate among the rods.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the livestock were feeble, he did not put them in. So the weaker were Laban’s and the stronger Jacob’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man became exceedingly prosperous and had many sheep and female servants and male servants and camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob heard the words of Laban’s sons, saying, “Jacob has taken away all that was our father’s, and he has gotten all his wealth from what was our father’s.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob saw the look of Laban and saw he was not congenial toward him as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your fathers, to your family, and I will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to the field where his flock was,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to them, “I see your father’s demeanor, that it is not congenial toward me as before; but the God of my father has been with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that with all my strength I have served your father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your father has deceived me and changed my wages ten times, but God did not allow him to hurt me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he said, ‘The speckled will be your wages,’ then all the flock produced speckled. If he said, ‘The striped will be your pay,’ then all the flock produced striped.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way God has taken away your father’s flock and given them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the livestock conceived, I lifted up my eyes and saw in a dream that the male goats mating with the flock were striped, speckled, and spotted.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of God spoke to me in a dream, saying, ‘Jacob.’ And I said, ‘Here I am.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘Now lift up your eyes and see all the male goats which mate with the flock are striped, speckled, and spotted, for I have seen all that Laban has done to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed the pillar, where you vowed a vow to Me. Now arise, and get out of this land, and return to the land of your family.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel and Leah answered him, “Is there any portion or inheritance left for us in our father’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: Are we not seen by him as foreigners? For he has sold us and has completely spent our money also.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all the riches which God has taken from our father are ours and our children’s. Now then, whatever God has said to you, do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob rose up and set his sons and his wives on camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he carried away all his livestock and all his goods which he had obtained, his acquired livestock which he had gotten in Paddan Aram, in order to go to Isaac his father in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Laban went to shear his sheep, Rachel stole the household idols that were her father’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob also deceived Laban the Syrian by not telling him that he was fleeing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob fled with all that he had, and he rose up and passed over the river and headed toward the mountains of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban was told on the third day that Jacob had fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took his kinsmen with him and pursued him for seven days until he caught up with him in the mountains of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God came to Laban the Syrian in a dream by night and said to him, “Take care that you speak to Jacob neither good nor bad.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban overtook Jacob. Now Jacob had pitched his tent on the mountain, and Laban with his kinsmen pitched in the mountains of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to Jacob, “What have you done that you have stolen away without my knowing and carried away my daughters like captives taken with the sword?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you flee away secretly and sneak away from me and not tell me? I would have sent you away with joy and with songs, with the tambourine and harp.
speaker: Narrator

text: And why did you not permit me to kiss my sons and my daughters farewell? You have acted foolishly in so doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is in my power to do you harm, but the God of your father spoke to me last night, saying, ‘Take care that you not speak to Jacob either good or bad.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you surely have gone away because you longed desperately after your father’s house, yet why have you stolen my gods?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob answered and said to Laban, “Because I was afraid, for I thought that you would take your daughters from me by force.
speaker: Narrator

text: But anyone with whom you find your gods, let him not live. In the presence of our kinsmen, point out what I have that is yours and take it.” For Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Laban went into Jacob’s tent and into Leah’s tent and into the two female servants’ tents, but he did not find them. Then he went out of Leah’s tent and entered into Rachel’s tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rachel had taken the household idols and put them in the camel’s saddle and sat on them. Laban searched the entire tent, but could not find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to her father, “Let not my lord be displeased that I cannot rise before you, for the manner of women is on me.” So he searched, but he did not find the household idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob became angry and berated Laban. And Jacob asked Laban, “What is my offense? What is my sin that you have so hotly pursued after me?
speaker: Narrator

text: You have searched all my things, and yet what have you found of all your household things? Set it here before my kinsmen and your kinsmen, so that they may judge between us both.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This twenty years I have been with you. Your ewes and your female goats have not miscarried their young, and the male goats of your flock I have not eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: That which was torn by beasts I did not bring to you. I bore the loss of it. You required it from my hand whether it was stolen by day or stolen by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was like this with me: In the day the heat consumed me and the frost by night, and my sleep fled from my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been twenty years in your house. I served you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flock, and you have changed my wages ten times.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had not been with me, surely you would have sent me away empty now. God has seen my affliction and the labor of my hands and rebuked you last night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban answered and said to Jacob, “These daughters are my daughters, and these children are my children, and the flocks are my flocks, and all that you see is mine. But what can I do this day to my daughters or to their children whom they have borne?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore come, let us make a covenant, you and I, and let it be as a witness between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob took a stone and set it up for a pillar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to his kinsmen, “Gather stones.” So they took stones and made a pile, and they ate there on the pile.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Laban called it Jegar Sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “This pile is a witness between me and you this day.” Therefore its name was called Galeed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Mizpah, for he said, “May the Lord watch between you and me, when we are apart from one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you mistreat my daughters, or if you take other wives beside my daughters, although no one else is with us, remember that God is witness between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban said to Jacob, “See this pile and see this pillar which I have thrown between you and me.
speaker: Narrator

text: This heap is a witness, and this pillar is a witness, so that I will not cross over this pile to you and so that you will not pass over this pile and this pillar to me for harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God of Abraham, the God of Nahor, and the God of their father, judge between us.”
Then Jacob vowed by the Fear of his father Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob offered a sacrifice on the mountain and called his kinsmen to eat bread. And they ate bread and stayed all night on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the morning Laban rose up, kissed his grandchildren and his daughters, and blessed them. Then Laban departed and returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob went on his way, and the angels of God met him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob saw them, he said, “This is God’s camp.” So he called the name of that place Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob sent messengers before him to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He commanded them, saying, “This is what you must say to my lord Esau: This is what your servant Jacob says, ‘I have sojourned with Laban and stayed there until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have oxen and donkeys, flocks, and male servants and female servants, and I am sending this message to tell my lord, so that I may find favor in your sight.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers returned to Jacob, saying, “We went to your brother Esau. He is coming to meet you, and what is more, four hundred men are with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob was very afraid and distressed, and he divided the people that were with him, along with the flocks and herds and the camels, into two groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If Esau comes to the one camp and attacks it, then the other camp which is left may escape.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob said, “O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, the Lord who said to me, ‘Return to your country and to your relatives, and I will prosper you,’
speaker: Narrator

text: I am not worthy of all the lovingkindness and of all the faithfulness which You have shown to Your servant. For with my staff I crossed over this Jordan, and now I have become two encampments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deliver me, I pray, from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau. For I fear him, that he will come and attack me and the mothers with the children.
speaker: Narrator

text: You said, ‘I will surely prosper you and make your descendants as the sand of the sea, which is too many to be counted.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he spent the night there. Then he selected from what he had with him a gift for his brother Esau:
speaker: Narrator

text: two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: thirty female camels with their colts, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave them to his servants, every drove by itself, and said to his servants, “Pass over before me, and keep a distance between each drove.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He commanded the one leading, saying, “When my brother Esau meets you and asks you, saying, ‘To whom do you belong, and where are you going, and to whom do these animals belong?’
speaker: Narrator

text: then you are to say, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob. They are a gift sent to my lord Esau, and he is also behind us.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise he commanded the second and the third and all that followed the droves, saying, “This is what you are to say to Esau when you find him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, say, ‘Your servant Jacob is behind us.’ ” For he said, “I will appease him with the gift that goes before me, and then I will see his face. Perhaps he will accept me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the gift went before him, but he lodged that night in the encampment.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same night he arose and took his two wives, his two female servants, and his eleven sons, and crossed over the ford of the Jabbok.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took them and sent them across the stream along with all that he had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob was left alone, and a man wrestled with him there until daybreak.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man saw that He did not prevail against Jacob, He touched the socket of his thigh, so the socket of Jacob’s thigh was dislocated, as he wrestled with Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then He said, “Let Me go, for the day breaks.”
But Jacob said, “I will not let You go, unless You bless me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So He said to him, “What is your name?”
And he said, “Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man said, “Your name will no more be called Jacob, but Israel. For you have fought with God and with men, and have prevailed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jacob asked Him, “Tell me, I pray You, Your name.”
But He said, “Why do you ask Me My name?” Then He blessed him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob called the name of the place Peniel, saying, “I have seen God face to face, and my life has been preserved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he crossed over Peniel, the sun rose over him, and he was limping on his thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore to this day the children of Israel do not eat the sinew which is attached to the socket of the thigh, because He touched the socket of Jacob’s thigh in the sinew of the hip.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming and four hundred men with him. So he divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and the two female servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the female servants and their children in front, then Leah and her children next, and then Rachel and Joseph last.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went on before them, bowing himself to the ground seven times, until he came near to his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Esau ran to meet him and embraced him and fell on his neck and kissed him, and they wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Esau looked up and saw the women and the children, he said, “Who are those with you?”
Jacob said, “The children whom God has graciously given your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the female servants came near, they and their children, and they bowed down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah also with her children came near and bowed themselves. Afterward Joseph and Rachel came near, and they bowed themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Esau said, “What do you mean by all this company that I met?”
Jacob answered, “These are to find favor in the sight of my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “I have enough, my brother. Keep what you have for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “No, I pray you, if I have now found favor in your sight, then receive my gift from my hand. For I have seen your face, and it is as though I have seen the face of God, with you having received me favorably.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please take my blessing that has been brought to you, because God has dealt graciously with me and because I have plenty.” So he urged him, and he took it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau said, “Let us journey on our way, and I will go ahead of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said to him, “My lord knows that the children are weak, and the flocks and herds with young are with me. If they are driven too hard one day, all the flock will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let my lord pass over before his servant, and I will lead on slowly, according to the pace of the livestock that goes before me and the pace the children will be able to endure, until I come to my lord at Seir.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Esau said, “Let me leave some of the people that are with me with you.”
But Jacob said, “What need is there? Let me find favor in the sight of my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau returned that day making his way back to Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob journeyed to Sukkoth and built himself a house and made booths for his livestock. Therefore the name of the place is called Sukkoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob came peacefully to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, on his way from Paddan Aram, and camped before the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bought a parcel of a field, where he had pitched his tent, from the children of Hamor, Shechem’s father, for a hundred pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: He erected an altar there and called it El Elohe Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Dinah, the daughter of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob, went out to see the daughters of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shechem, the son of Hamor the Hivite, prince of the land, saw her, he took her and lay with her and defiled her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was very smitten by Dinah the daughter of Jacob, and he loved the girl and spoke kindly to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shechem spoke to his father Hamor, saying, “Get me this girl for my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob heard that Shechem had violated his daughter Dinah, but his sons were with his livestock in the field, so Jacob held his peace until they came.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hamor the father of Shechem went out to Jacob to commune with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jacob came out of the field when they heard it, and the men were grieved and were very disturbed, because Shechem had disgraced Israel by lying with Jacob’s daughter, a thing that should not be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hamor spoke with them, saying, “The soul of my son Shechem longs for your daughter. I pray that you will give her to him to marry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make marriages with us, and give your daughters to us, and take our daughters for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may dwell with us, and the land will be before you. Dwell and trade in it and get possessions in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shechem said to her father and to her brothers, “Let me find favor in your eyes, and whatever you say to me I will give.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can make the dowry and gift I must bring high, and I will give according to what you say to me. Just give me the girl to marry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father deceitfully, because he had defiled Dinah their sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to them, “We cannot do this. To give our sister to one who is uncircumcised would be a disgrace to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we will consent to you in this: If you will become as we are, that is, every one of your males be circumcised,
speaker: Narrator

text: then we will give our daughters to you, and we will take your daughters to us, and we will dwell with you, and we will become one people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you will not listen to us and be circumcised, then we will take our daughter, and we will leave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Their words pleased Hamor and Shechem, Hamor’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man did not delay to do the thing, because he wanted Jacob’s daughter. Now he was more respected than all the household of his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hamor and Shechem his son came to the gate of their city, and they spoke with the men of their city, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “These men are at peace with us. Therefore let them dwell in the land and trade in it. For the land is large enough for them. Let us take their daughters as our wives, and let us give them our daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only on this condition will the men consent to dwell with us and be one people: if every male among us will be circumcised as they are circumcised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will not their livestock and their possessions and every animal of theirs be ours? Only, let us agree with them, and they will dwell with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All who went out of the gate of his city listened to Hamor and Shechem his son, and every male was circumcised, all who went out of the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, when they were in pain, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, took their swords and went to the unsuspecting city and killed all the males.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed Hamor and Shechem his son with the edge of the sword and took Dinah out of the house of Shechem and departed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jacob came upon the slain and looted the city, because they had defiled their sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their flocks and their herds, their donkeys and whatever was in the city and in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took captive and looted all their wealth, all their little ones, and their wives, even all that was in each house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought trouble on me by making me revolting among the inhabitants of the land, among the Canaanites and the Perizzites. Our being few in number, they will gather themselves together against me and slay me, and I will be destroyed, both I and my household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “Should he treat our sister like a prostitute?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Jacob, “Arise, go up to Bethel, dwell there, and there make an altar to God, who appeared to you when you fled from the face of Esau your brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, “Put away the foreign gods that are among you. Purify yourselves and change your clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us arise and go up to Bethel, and there I will make an altar to God, who answered me in the day of my distress and has been with me wherever I have gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods which were in their possession and all their earrings which were in their ears, and Jacob hid them under the oak which was near Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they traveled, the terror of God was on the cities that were around them, and they did not pursue the sons of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob came to Luz (that is, Bethel), which is in the land of Canaan, he and all the people who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: There he built an altar and called the place El Bethel, because God had appeared to him there when he fled from his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died and was buried beneath Bethel under the oak. So it was called Allon Bakuth.
speaker: Narrator

text: God appeared to Jacob again when he came out of Paddan Aram and blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “Your name is Jacob. Your name shall not be called Jacob any more, but Israel shall be your name.” So He called his name Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “I am God Almighty. Be fruitful and multiply. A nation and a company of nations will come from you, and kings shall come forth from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land that I gave Abraham and Isaac, I will give to you, and to your descendants after you I will give the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God went up from him in the place where He had spoken with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob set up a pillar in the place where He had spoken with him, a pillar of stone, and he poured out a drink offering on it, and he poured oil on it too.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob called the name of the place where God had spoken with him Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They journeyed from Bethel, and when they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel went into labor, and she had a difficult labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she was in hard labor, the midwife said to her, “Do not fear. You will have this son also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As her soul was departing (for she died), she called his name Ben-Oni, but his father called him Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath, which is Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob set a pillar on her grave. It is the pillar of Rachel’s grave to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel journeyed and pitched his tent beyond the tower of Eder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Israel lived in that land, Reuben went and lay with Bilhah, his father’s concubine, and Israel heard about it.
Now the sons of Jacob were twelve:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Leah were
Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn,
and Simeon and Levi and Judah and Issachar and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Rachel were
Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the sons of Bilhah, Rachel’s maidservant, were
Dan and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the sons of Zilpah, Leah’s maidservant, were
Gad and Asher.
These are the sons of Jacob, which were born to him in Paddan Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob came back to Isaac his father in Mamre of Kiriath Arba (which is Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had sojourned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the days of Isaac were one hundred and eighty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaac breathed his last and died and was gathered to his people, being old and full of days, and his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the generations of Esau, who is Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau took his wives from the daughters of Canaan: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Basemath, Ishmael’s daughter, sister of Nebaioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah bore to Esau Eliphaz, and Basemath bore Reuel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, and all the people of his house, his livestock, all his animals, and all his property that he had acquired in the land of Canaan, and he moved to a land some distance from his brother Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: For their possessions were too great for them to dwell together, and the land where they were foreigners could not sustain them because of their livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau settled in the hill country of Seir. Esau is Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the generations of Esau the father of the Edomites in the hill country of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the names of Esau’s sons:
Eliphaz the son of Adah the wife of Esau, and Reuel the son of Basemath the wife of Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Eliphaz were
Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timna was a concubine to Eliphaz, Esau’s son, and she bore to Eliphaz Amalek. These were the sons of Adah, Esau’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the sons of Reuel:
Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the sons of Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah the daughter of Zibeon, Esau’s wife: she bore to Esau
Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were chiefs of the sons of Esau.
The sons of Eliphaz the firstborn son of Esau were
Chief Teman, Chief Omar, Chief Zepho, Chief Kenaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Chief Korah, Chief Gatam, and Chief Amalek. These are the chiefs who came from Eliphaz in the land of Edom. These were the sons of Adah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the sons of Reuel Esau’s son:
Chief Nahath, Chief Zerah, Chief Shammah, and Chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs who came from Reuel in the land of Edom. These were the sons of Basemath, Esau’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the sons of Oholibamah, Esau’s wife:
Chief Jeush, Chief Jalam, and Chief Korah. These were the chiefs who came from Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, Esau’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Esau, who is Edom, and these were their chiefs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the sons of Seir the Horite, who inhabited the land:
Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These were the chiefs of the Horites, the children of Seir in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The children of Lotan were
Hori and Homam, and Lotan’s sister was Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The children of Shobal were these:
Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the children of Zibeon:
Aiah and Anah. This was the Anah who found the water in the wilderness as he fed the donkeys of Zibeon, his father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The children of Anah were these:
Dishon and Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the children of Dishon:
Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The children of Ezer were these:
Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The children of Dishan were these:
Uz and Aran.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the chiefs that came from the Horites:
Chief Lotan, Chief Shobal, Chief Zibeon, Chief Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Chief Dishon, Chief Ezer, and Chief Dishan. These are the chiefs who came from Hori, among their chiefs in the land of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before there reigned any king over the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom, and the name of his city was Dinhabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela died, and Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jobab died, and Husham of the land of Temani reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Husham died, and Hadad the son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his stead, and the name of his city was Avith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samlah died, and Shaul of Rehoboth by the river reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaul died, and Baal-Hanan the son of Akbor reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baal-Hanan the son of Akbor died, and Hadad reigned in his stead, and the name of his city was Pau. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Me-Zahab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the names of the chiefs who came from Esau, according to their families, according to their places, by their names:
Chief Timnah, Chief Alvah, Chief Jetheth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Chief Oholibamah, Chief Elah, Chief Pinon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Chief Kenaz, Chief Teman, Chief Mibzar,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Chief Magdiel, and Chief Iram. These were the chiefs of Edom, according to their settlements in the land of their possession.
Esau was the father of the Edomites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob lived in the land where his father was a foreigner, in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the generations of Jacob.
Joseph, being seventeen years old, was feeding the flock with his brothers, and the boy was with the sons of Bilhah and with the sons of Zilpah, his father’s wives. Joseph brought back a bad report about them to their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his sons, because he was the son of his old age, and he made him a coat of many colors.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when his brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers, they hated him and could not speak peaceably to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joseph dreamed a dream, and when he told it to his brothers, they hated him even more.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Please listen to this dream which I have dreamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: We were binding sheaves in the field. All of a sudden my sheaf rose up and stood upright, and your sheaves stood around it and bowed down to my sheaf.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His brothers said to him, “Will you really reign over us, or will you really have dominion over us?” So they hated him even more because of his dreams and his words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he dreamed another dream and told it to his brothers and said, “I have dreamed another dream. The sun and the moon and eleven stars were bowing to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when he told it to his father and his brothers, his father rebuked him and said to him, “What is this dream that you have dreamed? Will I and your mother and your brothers really come to bow down ourselves to you to the ground?”
speaker: Narrator
