text: So his brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept the matter in mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now his brothers went to feed their father’s flock in Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel said to Joseph, “Are not your brothers feeding the flock in Shechem? Come, and I will send you to them.”
He answered, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said to him, “Please go and see if it is well with your brothers and well with the flocks, and bring back word to me.” So he sent him out of the Valley of Hebron, and he came to Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: A certain man found him wandering in the field. The man asked him, “What are you looking for?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “I am looking for my brothers. Please tell me where they are feeding their flocks.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The man said, “They have departed from here. I heard them say, ‘Let us go to Dothan.’ ”
So Joseph went after his brothers and found them in Dothan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw him some distance away, before he came near to them, they conspired against him to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said one to another, “The master of dreams comes!
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, let us kill him and throw him into some pit, and we will say, ‘Some evil beast has devoured him.’ Then we will see what will become of his dreams.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Reuben heard it, he rescued him out of their hands, saying, “Let us not kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben said to them, “Shed no blood, but throw him into this pit here in the wilderness, but lay no hand on him,” so that he might rescue him out of their hands and deliver him to his father again.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped Joseph of his coat—his coat of many colors that he had on.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they took him and threw him into a pit. The pit was empty, and there was no water in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sat down to eat. And looking up, they saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead, with their camels bearing spices, balm, and myrrh, carrying it down to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to his brothers, “What profit is it if we kill our brother and cover up his blood?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us sell him to the Ishmaelites, and let us not lay our hand on him, for he is our brother and our own flesh.” So his brothers agreed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when the Midianite merchants passed by, they drew Joseph up and lifted him out of the pit and sold Joseph to the Ishmaelites for twenty shekels of silver. They took Joseph to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Reuben returned to the pit and saw that Joseph was not in the pit, he tore his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He returned to his brothers, and said, “The boy is not there, and I, where can I go?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They took Joseph’s coat and killed a young goat and dipped the coat in the blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took the coat of many colors and brought it to their father and said, “This we have found. Do you know whether it is your son’s robe or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He knew it and said, “It is my son’s coat. A wild beast has devoured him. Joseph has without a doubt been torn into pieces.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob tore his clothes and put sackcloth on his waist and mourned for his son many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: All his sons and all his daughters rose up to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. And he said, “For I will go down into the grave mourning for my son.” So his father wept for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile the Midianites sold him in Egypt to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh and captain of the guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Judah left his brothers and visited a certain Adullamite, whose name was Hirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: There Judah saw the daughter of a certain Canaanite, whose name was Shua, and he took her and had relations with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived and bore a son, and he called his name Er.
speaker: Narrator

text: She conceived again and bore a son, and she called his name Onan.
speaker: Narrator

text: She again conceived and bore a son and called his name Shelah. He was at Kezib when she bore him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah took a wife for Er his firstborn, whose name was Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Er, Judah’s firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the Lord, so the Lord killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to Onan, “Go have relations with your brother’s wife, and marry her, and raise up descendants for your brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Onan knew that the descendant would not be his, so when he had relations with his brother’s wife, he let his semen go on the ground, so that he would not give a descendant to his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: What he did displeased the Lord; therefore He killed him also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to Tamar, his daughter-in-law, “Remain a widow at your father’s house until Shelah my son grows up.” For he thought, “He may die also, just as his brothers did.” So Tamar went and lived in her father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: As time went on, the daughter of Shua, Judah’s wife, died. After Judah was consoled, he went up to his sheepshearers in Timnah, he and his friend Hirah the Adullamite.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was told to Tamar, “Your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She took off her widow’s clothing, covered herself with a veil, wrapped herself up, and sat in an open place, which is by the road to Timnah. For she saw that Shelah was grown, and she was not given to him as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute, because she had covered her face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He turned to her by the road and said, “Come now, let me have relations with you” (for he did not know that she was his daughter-in-law).
And she said, “What will you give me, so that you may have relations with me?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said, “I will send you a young goat from the flock.”
And she said, “Will you give me a pledge, until you send it?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said, “What pledge should I give you?”
And she said, “Your signet, your bracelets, and your staff that is in your hand.” So he gave them to her and had relations with her, and she conceived by him.
speaker: Narrator

text: She arose and went away, and taking off her veil, she put on her widow’s clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah sent the young goat by his friend the Adullamite to receive his pledge from the woman’s hand, but he could not find her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he asked the men of the place, “Where is the cult prostitute who was at Enaim by the road?”
And they said, “There was no prostitute in this place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he returned to Judah and said, “I cannot find her. Also, the men of the place said there was no cult prostitute in this place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah replied, “Let her keep them for herself, or we shall be laughed at. I sent this young goat, and you did not find her.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
After about three months, it was told Judah, “Tamar your daughter-in-law has turned to prostitution, and what is more, as a result of prostitution she is pregnant.”
Then Judah said, “Bring her forth, and let her be burned!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When she was brought forth, she sent word to her father-in-law, saying, “By the man to whom these belong am I with child.” And she said, “Please identify whose these are—the signet and bracelet and staff.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah recognized them and said, “She has been more righteous than I, because I did not give her to Shelah my son.” He did not have relations with her again.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was time for her to give birth, there were twins in her womb.
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was giving birth, one put out his hand, and the midwife took and tied on his hand a scarlet thread, saying, “This one came out first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But as he drew back his hand, his brother came out. Then she said, “How have you made a breach for yourself?” Therefore his name was called Perez.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward his brother came out, the one that had the scarlet thread on his hand, and his name was called Zerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joseph was brought down to Egypt, and Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had brought him down there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with Joseph, so that he became a prosperous man. He was in the house of his master, the Egyptian.
speaker: Narrator

text: His master saw that the Lord was with him and that the Lord made all that he did to prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph found favor in his sight and served him. So he made him overseer over his house, and all that he had he put under his charge.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the time that he had made him overseer in his house and over all that he had, the Lord blessed the Egyptian’s house on account of Joseph. So the blessing of the Lord was on all that he had in the house and in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he left all that he had in Joseph’s charge, and he had no concerns regarding anything except the food he ate.
Now Joseph was handsome and well-built.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a time, his master’s wife took notice of Joseph and said, “Lie with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he refused and said to his master’s wife, “My master does not concern himself with anything concerning me in the house, and he has committed all that he has to my charge.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is none greater in this house than I. He has kept nothing back from me but you, because you are his wife. How then can I do this great wickedness and sin against God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She spoke to Joseph every day, but he did not listen to her about lying with her or being with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it happened one day that Joseph went into the house to do his work, and none of the men of the house was there.
speaker: Narrator

text: She caught him by his clothing, saying, “Lie with me.” But he left his clothing in her hand and fled and got outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she saw that he had left his clothing in her hand and had fled outside,
speaker: Narrator

text: she called to the men of her house and spoke to them, saying, “See, he has brought in a Hebrew among us to humiliate us. He came in to me to lie with me, and I cried out with a loud voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard that I lifted up my voice and cried out, he left his clothing with me, fled, and got outside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She laid up his clothing next to her until his master came home.
speaker: Narrator

text: She spoke to him using these words, saying, “The Hebrew servant, whom you have brought to us, came in to me to mock me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I lifted up my voice and cried out, he left his clothing with me and fled outside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When his master heard the words of his wife, which she spoke to him, saying, “This is what your servant did to me,” he became enraged.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joseph’s master took him and put him into the prison, a place where the king’s prisoners were confined.
So he was there in the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was with Joseph and showed him mercy and gave him favor in the sight of the keeper of the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: The keeper of the prison committed all the prisoners that were in the prison to the charge of Joseph. So whatever they did there, he was the one responsible for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The keeper of the prison did not concern himself with anything that was under Joseph’s charge because the Lord was with him. And whatever he did, the Lord made it to prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometime after this, the cupbearer of the king of Egypt and his baker offended their lord, the king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was angry with his two officials, with the chief of the cupbearers and with the chief of the bakers.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he put them in confinement in the house of the captain of the guard, in the prison, the place where Joseph was confined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The captain of the guard charged Joseph with them, and he attended to them.
They continued to be in confinement for some time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the cupbearer and the baker for the king of Egypt, who were confined in the prison, both had a dream the same night, each man with his own dream and each dream with its own interpretation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph came in to them in the morning and looked at them and realized they were sad.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he asked Pharaoh’s officials who were with him in the care of his lord’s house, saying, “Why do you look so sad today?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they said to him, “We have dreamed a dream, and there is no interpreter for it.”
Then Joseph said to them, “Do not interpretations belong to God? Please tell them to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The chief cupbearer told his dream to Joseph and said to him, “In my dream, a vine was in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the vine there were three branches. As it budded, its blossoms shot forth and its clusters brought forth ripe grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand, and I took the grapes, and pressed them into Pharaoh’s cup, and I put the cup into Pharaoh’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to him, “This is the interpretation of it. The three branches are three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within three days Pharaoh will lift up your head and restore you to your place, and you will deliver Pharaoh’s cup into his hand in the same way you did before when you were his cupbearer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But remember me when it is well with you, and show kindness, I pray you, to me, and make mention of me to Pharaoh, and get me out of this house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I was indeed kidnapped out of the land of the Hebrews, and I have done nothing that they should put me in the dungeon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was good, he said to Joseph, “I also was in my dream, and I had three white baskets on my head.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the uppermost basket there was all manner of baked goods for Pharaoh, and the birds ate them out of the basket on my head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph answered and said, “This is the interpretation: The three baskets are three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within three days Pharaoh will lift your head from off you and will hang you on a tree, and the birds will eat your flesh from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It happened on the third day, which was Pharaoh’s birthday, that he made a feast for all his servants. He lifted up the heads of the chief cupbearer and the chief baker among his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He restored the chief cupbearer to his position again, and he put the cup into Pharaoh’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, he hanged the chief baker, just as Joseph had interpreted to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, the chief cupbearer did not remember Joseph, but forgot him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After two whole years, Pharaoh had a dream that he was standing by the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven fine-looking and fattened cows suddenly came up out of the river, and they grazed in the meadow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then seven other cows came up after them out of the river, ugly and gaunt, and stood by the other cows on the riverbank.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ugly and gaunt cows ate up the seven fine-looking and fattened cows. Then Pharaoh awoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: He slept and dreamed a second time. Seven ears of grain suddenly came up on one stalk, plump and good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then seven thin ears, scorched by the east wind, sprang up after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven thin ears devoured the seven plump and full ears. Then Pharaoh awoke and realized it was a dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning his spirit was troubled, and he sent and called for all the magicians of Egypt and all its wise men. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but there was no one who could interpret them to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the chief cupbearer spoke to Pharaoh, saying, “Today I remember my offenses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was angry with his servants and put me in confinement in the captain of the guard’s house, both me and the chief baker.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we had a dream in the same night, he and I. We, each of us, dreamed according to the interpretation of his own dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young Hebrew man was with us there, a servant to the captain of the guard. We told him and he interpreted our dreams for us. To each man he interpreted according to his own dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: It happened just as he interpreted. He restored me to my position, and the baker was hanged.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh sent and called for Joseph, and they brought him hastily out of the dungeon. He shaved himself, changed his clothes, and came to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I have dreamed a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it. I have heard it said of you that you can understand a dream to interpret it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, “It is not in me. God will give Pharaoh a favorable answer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “In my dream, I stood on the bank of the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: And suddenly there came up out of the river seven cows, fattened and fine-looking, and they grazed in the reeds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then seven other cows came up after them, poor and very ugly and gaunt. I have never seen such ugliness in all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the gaunt and ugly cows ate up the first seven fat cows.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had eaten them up, no one would have known that they had eaten them, for they were still as ugly as before. Then I awoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I also saw in my dreams seven ears of grain, full and good, suddenly come up on one stalk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then seven ears, thin and scorched by the east wind, sprang up after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the thin ears swallowed the seven good ears. So I told this to the magicians, but there was no one who could explain it to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, “The dreams of Pharaoh are one and the same. God has shown Pharaoh what He is about to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good ears are seven years. The dreams are one.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven gaunt and ugly cows that came up after them are seven years, and the seven empty ears scorched by the east wind will be seven years of famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is as I have spoken to Pharaoh. God has shown Pharaoh what He is about to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven years of great abundance will come throughout all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, there will arise after them seven years of famine. All the abundance will be forgotten in the land of Egypt, and the famine will consume the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The abundance will be unknown in the land because of the famine following, for it will be very severe.
speaker: Narrator

text: The reason the dream was repeated to Pharaoh twice is because the matter is established by God, and God will soon bring it to pass.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, therefore, let Pharaoh seek out a man who is discerning and wise and set him over the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let Pharaoh do this, and let him appoint officials over the land and collect the fifth part of the produce of the land of Egypt in the seven abundant years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them gather all the food from those good years that come and lay up grain under the authority of Pharaoh, and let them keep food in the cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: This food will be for a reserve for the land for the seven years of famine which will be in the land of Egypt, so that the land does not perish during the famine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The counsel seemed good to Pharaoh and to all of his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to his servants, “Can we find anyone like this man, in whom is the Spirit of God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Since God has shown you all this, there is no one as discerning and wise as you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be over my house, and according to your word all my people will be ruled. Only in regard to the throne will I be greater than you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “See, I have set you over all the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh took off his ring from his hand and put it on Joseph’s hand and arrayed him in clothes of fine linen and put a gold chain around his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he had him ride in the second chariot which was his, and they cried out before him, “Bow the knee!” So he set him over all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, and without your consent no man will lift up his hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh called Joseph’s name Zaphenath-Paneah, and he gave him a wife, Asenath the daughter of Potiphera priest of On. And Joseph went out over all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh and went throughout all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seven abundant years the earth brought forth plentifully.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he gathered up all the food of the seven years which was in the land of Egypt and laid up the food in the cities. He put in every city the food of the fields which surrounded the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph gathered great quantities of grain as the sand of the sea until he stopped measuring it, for it was beyond measure.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before the years of famine came, two sons were born to Joseph, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, bore to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph called the name of the firstborn Manasseh, “For God,” he said, “has made me forget all my trouble and all my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the second he called Ephraim, saying, “For God has caused me to be fruitful in the land of my affliction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven years of abundance that were in the land of Egypt ended.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven years of famine began to come, just as Joseph had said. The famine was in all lands, but there was food in all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the land of Egypt was hungry, the people cried to Pharaoh for food, and Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, “Go to Joseph. Do whatever he says to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The famine was over all the face of the earth, so Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold to the Egyptians, and the famine was severe throughout the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, all countries came to Egypt to Joseph to buy grain, because the famine was so severe in all the lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Jacob saw that there was grain in Egypt, Jacob said to his sons, “Why do you look at one another?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy some for us, so that we may live and not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s ten brothers went down to buy grain in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob did not send Benjamin, Joseph’s brother, with his brothers for he said, “Perhaps some harm might happen to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the sons of Israel came to buy grain among those who came, for the famine was in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joseph was the governor over the land, and it was he who sold to all the people of the land. So Joseph’s brothers came and bowed themselves down before him with their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joseph saw his brothers, and he recognized them, but he pretended to be a stranger to them and spoke harshly to them. He said to them, “From where do you come?”
And they said, “From the land of Canaan to buy food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph knew his brothers, but they did not know him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph also remembered the dreams that he had dreamed of them. He said to them, “You are spies! You came to see the nakedness of the land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “No, my lord, your servants have come only to buy food.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are all one man’s sons. We are honest men. Your servants are not spies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to them, “No, you have come to see the nakedness of the land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Your servants are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. The youngest is with our father today, and one is no longer living.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to them, “It is as I said to you, ‘You are spies!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is how you will be tested. By the life of Pharaoh, you will not leave here unless your youngest brother comes here.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send one of you, and let him get your brother, and you will be kept in prison, so that your words may be tested, whether there be any truth in you. Or else, by the life of Pharaoh, you are surely spies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He put them all together in custody for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to them the third day, “Do this and live, for I fear God.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are honest men, let one of your brothers be confined in your prison house. The rest of you go and carry grain for the famine of your households.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, bring your youngest brother to me so that your words may be verified and you shall not die.” And they did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said one to another, “We are guilty concerning our brother, because we saw the anguish of his soul when he pleaded with us, but we would not listen. Therefore, this distress has come upon us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben answered them, saying, “Did I not speak to you, saying, ‘Do not sin against the boy’; and you would not listen? Therefore, his blood is now required of us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not know that Joseph understood them, for he spoke to them through an interpreter.
speaker: Narrator

text: He turned himself away from them and wept, but then turned back to them again and spoke with them. Then he took Simeon from them and bound him before their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph then gave the command to fill their sacks with grain and to restore every man’s money to his sack and to give them provisions for the way. And it was done for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They loaded their donkeys with the grain and departed from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: As one of them opened his sack to give his donkey feed in the lodging place, he saw his money. It was in the mouth of his sack.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said to his brothers, “My money has been returned. Here it is in my sack!”
Then their hearts sank, and they were afraid, saying to one another, “What is this that God has done to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to Jacob their father in the land of Canaan and told him all that had happened to them, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man, the lord of the land, spoke harshly to us and took us for spies of the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we said to him, ‘We are honest men. We are not spies.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are twelve brothers, all sons of our father. One is no longer living, and the youngest is with our father today in the land of Canaan.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man, the lord of the country, said to us, ‘Here is how I may know that you are honest men. Leave one of your brothers here with me, take food for the famine of your households, and be gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: But bring your youngest brother back to me. Then I will know that you are not spies, but that you are honest men. Then I will deliver your brother to you, and you may trade in the land.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they emptied their sacks, every man’s bundle of money was in his sack. When both they and their father saw the bundles of money, they were afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob their father said to them, “You have bereaved me of my children! Joseph is no more, Simeon is no more, and you will take Benjamin away. All these things are against me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben spoke to his father, saying, “Kill my two sons if I fail to bring him to you. Put him in my hands, and I will bring him back to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said, “My son must not go down with you, for his brother is dead, and he alone is left. If harm should happen to him on the journey you are to make, then you will bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the famine was severe in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had eaten up the grain which they had brought out of Egypt, their father said to them, “Go back and buy us a little food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah spoke to him, saying, “The man solemnly warned us, saying, ‘You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will send our brother with us, we will go down and buy food for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you will not send him, we will not go down. For the man said to us, ‘You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said, “Why did you treat me so badly as to tell the man that you had another brother?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “The man asked us directly about ourselves and our family, saying, ‘Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?’ So we answered his questions. How could we even know that he would say, ‘Bring your brother down’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Judah said to Israel his father, “Send the boy with me, and we will arise and go, so that we may live and not die, both we and you, and also our little ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be a surety for him. You may hold me personally responsible for him. If I fail to bring him back to you and set him before you, then let me bear the blame forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we had not delayed, we could have returned twice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father Israel said to them, “If it must be so, do this. Take some of the best fruits in the land in your bags, and carry down a present for the man: a little balm and a little honey, spices, and myrrh, pistachio nuts and almonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take double the money with you, along with the money that was brought back in the mouths of your sacks. Carry it with you again. Perhaps it was a mistake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, take your brother and arise, return to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text: And may God Almighty give you mercy before the man, so that he may send away your other brother, along with Benjamin. As for me, if I am bereaved, I am bereaved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men took the gift, and they took double the money with them, along with Benjamin. Then they went on their way down to Egypt and stood before Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the house steward, “Bring these men home, slaughter an animal and prepare it, for these men will dine with me at noon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man did as Joseph ordered, so the man brought the men into Joseph’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men were afraid because they were brought into Joseph’s house. They said, “We have been brought in because of the money that was returned in our sacks the first time, so that he may seek occasion against us and fall upon us and take us for slaves with our donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They approached the steward of Joseph’s house, and they spoke with him at the entrance of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “My lord, we indeed came down the first time to buy food.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we came to the lodging place, we opened our sacks and realized every man’s money was in the mouth of his sack, our money in full weight. So we have brought it again with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have also brought additional money with us to buy food. We cannot tell who put our money in our sacks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Be at peace; do not be afraid. Your God and the God of your father has given you treasure in your sacks. I had your money.” Then he brought Simeon out to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man brought the men into Joseph’s house and gave them water to wash their feet and gave feed to their donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they made ready the gift for Joseph’s coming at noon, for they heard that they would be eating a meal there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph came home, they brought into the house to him the present that they had with them and bowed themselves to him to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them about their well-being and said, “Is your father well, the old man of whom you spoke? Is he still alive?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they answered, “Your servant our father is in good health. He is still alive.” And they bowed down their heads and prostrated themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lifted up his eyes and saw his brother Benjamin, his mother’s son, and said, “Is this your younger brother of whom you spoke to me?” And he said, “God be gracious to you, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph hurried out, for he was deeply moved over his brother and sought a place to weep. So he entered into his chamber and wept there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he washed his face and came out. Controlling himself, he said, “Serve the food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They served him by himself and them by themselves and the Egyptians who ate with him by themselves, because the Egyptians could not eat a meal with the Hebrews, for that is an abomination to the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sat before him, the firstborn according to his birthright and the youngest according to his youth, and the men looked at one another in astonishment.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave them portions from his own table, but Benjamin’s serving was five times more than any of theirs. So they drank and feasted with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he commanded the steward of his house, saying, “Fill the men’s sacks with food, as much as they can carry, and put every man’s money in the mouth of his sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put my cup, the silver cup, in the mouth of the sack of the youngest, along with his grain money.” And he did according to what Joseph had spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the morning was light, the men were sent away, they and their donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were gone out of the city, but not yet far off, Joseph said to his steward, “Get up, follow after the men. When you overtake them, say to them, ‘Why have you rewarded evil for good?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this not the one from which my lord drinks and uses as he practices divination? You have done evil in doing this.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he overtook them, and he spoke to them these same words.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Why does my lord say these words? Far be it from your servants that they should do such a thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, we brought back to you from the land of Canaan the money that we found in the top of our sacks. Why then would we steal silver or gold from your lord’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: Whichever of your servants is found with it shall die, and the rest of us will become my lord’s slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Now let it also be according to your words. He with whom it is found shall be my slave, and you will be blameless.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then every man hurriedly took down his sack to the ground, and every man opened his sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: He searched, beginning with the oldest and ending with the youngest. The cup was found in Benjamin’s sack.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they tore their clothes, and every man loaded his donkey and returned to the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judah and his brothers came to Joseph’s house, he was still there; and they fell to the ground before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to them, “What deed is this that you have done? Did you not know that such a man as I can certainly practice divination?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Judah said, “What shall we say to my lord? What shall we speak? Or how shall we clear ourselves? God has found out the iniquity of your servants. Here we are, my lord’s servants, both we and he also in whose possession the cup was found.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “Far be it from me that I should do so. The man in whose possession the cup was found shall be my slave; but as for you, go up in peace to your father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah approached him and said, “O my lord, please let your servant speak a word in my lord’s ears, and do not be angry with your servant, for you are equal to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: My lord asked his servants, saying, ‘Have you a father or a brother?’
speaker: Narrator

text: And we said to my lord, ‘We have a father, an old man, and a young brother, the child of his old age. His brother is dead, and he alone is left of his mother, and his father loves him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “You said to your servants, ‘Bring him down to me, so that I may set my eyes on him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: We said to my lord, ‘The boy cannot leave his father, for if he should leave his father, his father would die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You said to your servants, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you will not see my face again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When we went back to your servant, my father, we told him the words of my lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Our father said, ‘Go again and buy us a little food.’
speaker: Narrator

text: We said, ‘We cannot go down. If our youngest brother is with us, then we will go down, for we may not see the man’s face, unless our youngest brother is with us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your servant, my father, said to us, ‘You know that my wife bore me two sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the one went out from me, and I said, “Surely he was torn in pieces,” and I have not seen him since.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you take this one also from me and he is harmed, you will bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore when I come to your servant, my father, and the boy is not with us, as his life is bound up in the boy’s life,
speaker: Narrator

text: when he sees that the boy is not with us, he will die, and your servants will bring down the gray hairs of your servant, our father, with sorrow to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your servant became surety for the boy to my father, saying, ‘If I fail to bring him to you, then I shall bear the blame to my father forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore, please let your servant stay as a slave to my lord instead of the boy, and let the boy go up with his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: For how can I go up to my father if the boy is not with me, lest perhaps I see the evil that would find my father?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph could not restrain himself before all who stood by him, and he cried out, “Make every man go out from me.” So no man stood with him when Joseph made himself known to his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He wept so loudly that the Egyptians and the house of Pharaoh heard about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph. Is my father still alive?” But his brothers could not answer him, for they were dismayed in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers, “Please come near to me,” and they came near. Then he said, “I am your brother, Joseph, whom you sold into Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now do not be upset or angry with yourselves because you sold me here, for God sent me before you to preserve life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For these two years the famine has been in the land, and there are still five years in which there will be neither plowing nor harvesting.
speaker: Narrator

text: God sent me ahead of you to preserve you as a remnant on the earth and to save your lives by a great deliverance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now it was not you who sent me here, but God. He has made me a father to Pharaoh and lord of his entire household and a ruler throughout all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurry and go up to my father and say to him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says, “God has made me lord of all Egypt. Come down to me; do not delay.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you will dwell in the land of Goshen, and you will be near me, you and your children and your children’s children, along with your flocks, your herds, and all that you have.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will provide for you there, for there are still five years of famine to come, lest you and your household, and all that you have, come to poverty.” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your eyes and the eyes of my brother Benjamin see that it is my mouth that is speaking to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must tell my father of all my glory in Egypt and of all that you have seen, and you must hurry and bring my father down here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he fell on his brother Benjamin’s neck and wept, and Benjamin wept on his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover he kissed all his brothers and wept on them. After that his brothers talked with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the news reached Pharaoh’s palace that Joseph’s brothers had come, it pleased Pharaoh and his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Say to your brothers, ‘Do this. Load your animals and go to the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get your father and your households and come to me, and I will give you the best of the land of Egypt, and you shall eat the fat of the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are also commanded to say, ‘Do this: Take your wagons out of the land of Egypt for your little ones and for your wives, and get your father and come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also do not concern yourself with your goods, for the best of all the land of Egypt is yours.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the sons of Israel did so, and Joseph gave them wagons, according to the commandment of Pharaoh, and gave them provisions for the journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: To each of them he gave a change of clothes, but he gave to Benjamin three hundred shekels of silver and five changes of clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: To his father he sent the following: ten donkeys loaded with the best things of Egypt and ten female donkeys loaded with grain and bread and provisions for his father on the journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he sent his brothers away, and they departed. He said to them, “Do not quarrel on the way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up out of Egypt and came to the land of Canaan to Jacob their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “Joseph is still alive, and he is governor over all the land of Egypt.” And Jacob’s heart stood still because he could not believe them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him all the words of Joseph, which he had said to them, and when he saw the wagons that Joseph had sent to carry him, the spirit of their father Jacob revived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel said, “Enough! Joseph my son is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel set out with all that he had and came to Beersheba and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God spoke to Israel in visions of the night and said, “Jacob, Jacob.”
And he said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then He said, “I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you into a great nation there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go down with you to Egypt, and I will also surely bring you back again. And Joseph’s own hand shall close your eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob arose from Beersheba, and the sons of Israel carried Jacob their father and their little ones and their wives in the wagons that Pharaoh had sent to carry him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their livestock and their possessions that they had acquired in the land of Canaan, and came to Egypt, Jacob and all his descendants with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought with him to Egypt his sons and his sons’ sons, his daughters and his sons’ daughters, and all his descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the names of the sons of Israel, Jacob and his sons, who came to Egypt:
Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Reuben were
Hanok, Pallu, Hezron, and Karmi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Simeon were
Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar, and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Levi were
Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Judah were
Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah (but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan).
The sons of Perez were
Hezron and Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Issachar were
Tola, Puah, Job, and Shimron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Zebulun were
Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan Aram, with his daughter Dinah. All his sons and his daughters numbered thirty-three.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the sons of Gad were
Zephon, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Asher were
Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah,
and Serah their sister.
The sons of Beriah:
Heber and Malkiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to Leah his daughter; and these she bore to Jacob, sixteen in all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Rachel, Jacob’s wife, were
Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Joseph in the land of Egypt were born Manasseh and Ephraim, whom Asenath the daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On, bore to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Benjamin were
Bela, Beker, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob, fourteen in all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The son of Dan was
Hushim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Naphtali:
Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to Rachel his daughter, and she bore these to Jacob, seven in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: All those who came with Jacob to Egypt, who were direct descendants, besides the wives of Jacob’s sons, were sixty-six in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Joseph, who were born to him in Egypt, were two. All those of the house of Jacob who came to Egypt were seventy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now he sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph to get directions to Goshen. And they came into the land of Goshen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph readied his chariot and went up to Goshen to meet Israel his father. As soon as he appeared to him, he fell on his neck and wept on his neck a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said to Joseph, “Now let me die, since I have seen your face, because you are still alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s household, “I will go up and tell Pharaoh and say to him, ‘My brothers and my father’s household, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men are shepherds; their work has been to feed livestock, and they have brought their flocks and their herds and all that they have.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh calls you and asks, ‘What is your occupation?’
speaker: Narrator

text: you shall say, ‘Your servants have been keepers of livestock from our youth even until now, both we and our fathers,’ so that you may dwell in the land of Goshen, because every shepherd is an abomination to the Egyptians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph went and told Pharaoh, “My father and my brothers and their flocks and their herds and all that they possess have come from the land of Canaan and are now in the land of Goshen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He took five men from among his brothers and presented them before Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pharaoh asked his brothers, “What is your occupation?”
And they said to Pharaoh, “Your servants are shepherds, both we and also our fathers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Pharaoh, “We have come to sojourn in the land, for your servants have no pasture for their flocks, because the famine is severe in the land of Canaan. Now therefore, please allow your servants to dwell in the land of Goshen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh spoke to Joseph, saying, “Your father and your brothers have come to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land of Egypt is before you. Have your father and your brothers dwell in the best of the land. Have them dwell in the land of Goshen, and if you know any capable men among them, then put them in charge over my livestock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph brought in Jacob his father and presented him to Pharaoh, and Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Jacob, “How old are you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob said to Pharaoh, “The days of the years of my pilgrimage are one hundred and thirty years. My days of the years of my life have been few and evil, and they have not attained to the days of the years of the lives of my fathers in the days of their pilgrimage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph settled his father and his brothers and gave them a possession in the land of Egypt, in the best part of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph provided food for his father, his brothers, and his father’s entire household, according to the number of their children.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no food in all the land, for the famine was very severe, so that the land of Egypt and all the land of Canaan languished because of the famine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph gathered up all the money that was found in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan for the grain that they bought, and Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the money was all spent in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan, all the Egyptians came to Joseph and said, “Give us food, for why should we die in your presence? For our money is gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said, “Give your livestock, and I will give you food for your livestock, if your money is gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought their livestock to Joseph, and Joseph gave them food in exchange for the horses, the flocks, the herds, and the donkeys; and he fed them with food in exchange for all their livestock for that year.
speaker: Narrator

text: When that year was ended, they came to him the second year and said to him, “We will not hide it from our lord, that our money is all spent. Our lord also has our herds of livestock. There is nothing left in the sight of my lord but our bodies and our lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should we die before your eyes, both we and our land? Buy us and our land for food, and we and our land will be slaves to Pharaoh. Also give us seed, so that we may live and not die, so that the land will not be desolate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh, for every Egyptian man sold his field because the famine was severe on them. So the land became Pharaoh’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the people, he removed them to cities from one end of the borders of Egypt to the other end.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only the land of the priests he did not buy; for the priests had an allotment from Pharaoh, and they lived off their allotment that Pharaoh gave them. Therefore they did not sell their lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph said to the people, “I have bought you and your land today for Pharaoh; here is seed for you so you may sow the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the harvest, you must give a fifth part to Pharaoh and four parts will be your own, as seed for the field and for your food and for those of your households and for food for your little ones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “You have saved our lives. Let us find grace in the sight of my lord, and we will be Pharaoh’s slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph made it a law over the land of Egypt to this day, that Pharaoh should have the fifth part, except from the land of the priests, which did not become Pharaoh’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel lived in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen, and they had possessions there and grew and became very numerous.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years, so the years of Jacob’s life were one hundred and forty-seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time drew near when Israel would die, he called his son Joseph and said to him, “If now I have found grace in your sight, please put your hand under my thigh and deal kindly and truly with me. Please do not bury me in Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but let me lie with my fathers. Carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their burial place.”
And he said, “I will do as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Swear to me,” and he swore to him. Then Israel bowed himself at the head of his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: After these things, Joseph was told, “Your father is sick.” So he took his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob was told, “Your son Joseph is coming to you,” Israel strengthened himself and sat up in the bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to Joseph, “God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan, and blessed me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He said to me, ‘I will make you fruitful and multiply you, and I will make you into a multitude of people and will give this land to your descendants after you for an everlasting possession.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now your two sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came to you in Egypt, are mine; as Reuben and Simeon, they shall be mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any children you have after them will be yours and will be called by the names of their brothers in their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for me, when I came from Paddan, Rachel died beside me in the land of Canaan on the way, when there was still some distance to get to Ephrath, and I buried her there on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel saw Joseph’s sons and said, “Whose are these?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Joseph said to his father, “They are my sons, whom God has given me in this place.”
And he said, “Please bring them to me, and I will bless them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the eyes of Israel were dim with age, so that he could not see. So Joseph brought them near to him, and he kissed them and embraced them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said to Joseph, “I never thought I would see your face, but here God has also shown me your children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph took them from beside his knees, and he bowed down with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph took them both, Ephraim in his right hand toward Israel’s left hand, and Manasseh in his left hand toward Israel’s right hand, and brought them near him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel stretched out his right hand and laid it on Ephraim’s head, who was the younger, and his left hand on Manasseh’s head, crossing his hands, for Manasseh was the firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He blessed Joseph and said,
“God, before whom my fathers
    Abraham and Isaac walked,
the God who fed me
    all my life long to this day,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: When Joseph saw that his father laid his right hand on the head of Ephraim, it displeased him, and he took hold of his father’s hand to remove it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his father, “Not so, my father, for this one is the firstborn. Put your right hand on his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His father refused and said, “I know it, my son, I know it. He will also become a people, and he will also be great, but truly his younger brother will be greater than he, and his descendants will become a multitude of nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He blessed them that day, saying,
“By you Israel will bless, saying,
    ‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.’ ”
So he set Ephraim before Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said to Joseph, “I am about to die, but God will be with you and return you again to the land of your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, I have given to you one portion more than your brothers, which I took out of the hand of the Amorites with my sword and my bow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob called to his sons and said, “Gather yourselves together, so that I may tell you what will befall you in the last days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gather yourselves together and hear, sons of Jacob,
    and listen to your father Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Reuben, you are my firstborn,
    my might and the beginning of my strength,
    the excellency of dignity, and the excellency of power.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Simeon and Levi are brothers;
    weapons of violence are their swords.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Cursed be their anger, for it is fierce;
    and their wrath, for it is cruel!
I will divide them in Jacob
    and scatter them in Israel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The scepter shall not depart from Judah,
    nor a lawgiver from between his feet,
until Shiloh comes;
    and to him will be the obedience of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He tethers his foal to the vine,
    and his colt to the choicest vine;
he washes his garments in wine,
    his clothes in the blood of grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes are darker than wine,
    and his teeth whiter than milk.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Issachar is a strong donkey,
    lying down between two burdens;

text:
he saw that a resting place was good,

so he bowed his shoulder to bear the burden

speaker: Narrator

text:
Dan shall judge his people
    as one of the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dan shall be a serpent by the road,
    a viper on the path,
that bites the horse’s heels
    so that its rider will fall backward.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wait for Your salvation, O Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gad shall be attacked by raiding bands,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Asher’s food shall be rich,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Naphtali is a doe set loose;
    he gives beautiful words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joseph is a fruitful bough,
    a fruitful bough by a spring,
    whose branches run over the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The archers bitterly attacked him,
    they shot at him and hated him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But his bow remained firm.
    His arms were agile
because of the hands of the Mighty One of Jacob,
    because of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because of the God of your father who will help you,
    and by the Almighty who will bless you
with blessings from heaven above,
    blessings from the deep that lies beneath,
    the blessings of the breasts and the womb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blessings of your father have surpassed
    the blessings of my fathers,
    up to the utmost bound of the everlasting hills.
They will be on the head of Joseph,
    and on the crown of the head of him who was set apart from his brothers.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: These are all the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father said to them when he blessed them. He blessed them, each with the blessing appropriate to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he charged them and said to them, “I am about to be gathered to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the cave that is in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
speaker: Narrator

text: in the cave that is in the field of Machpelah, which is before Mamre in the land of Canaan, which Abraham bought along with the field from Ephron the Hittite as a burial place.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried Abraham and Sarah his wife there. They buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife there, and I buried Leah there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The field and the cave that is there were purchased from the children of Heth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob finished instructing his sons, he drew his feet into the bed, breathed his last, and was gathered to his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph fell on his father’s face and wept over him and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph commanded his servants the physicians to embalm his father. So the physicians embalmed Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Forty days were required for him, for such is the time required for those who are embalmed. Then the Egyptians mourned for him seventy days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the days of his mourning were past, Joseph spoke to the household of Pharaoh, saying, “If now I have found favor in your eyes, speak to Pharaoh, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘My father made me swear, saying, “I am about to die. Bury me in my tomb which I dug for myself in the land of Canaan.” Now therefore please let me go up and bury my father, and then I will return.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said, “Go up and bury your father, as he made you swear to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph went up to bury his father, and all the servants of Pharaoh went up with him too, the elders of his household and all the elders of the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: all the house of Joseph and his brothers and his father’s household. They left only their little ones and their flocks and their herds in the land of Goshen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both the chariots and horsemen also went up with him. It was a very great company.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the threshing floor of Atad, which is beyond the Jordan, they mourned with a great and very sorrowful lamentation. He observed seven days of mourning for his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, saw the mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, “This is a grievous mourning for the Egyptians.” Therefore the place was called Abel Mizraim, which is beyond the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So his sons did with him just as he had commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For his sons carried him into the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah, near Mamre, which Abraham bought with the field as a burial site from Ephron the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had buried his father, Joseph returned to Egypt, he and his brothers and all who went up with him to bury his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, “Perhaps Joseph will hate us and will certainly pay us back for all the wrong we did to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent a message to Joseph, saying, “Your father gave this command before he died:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Say to Joseph, “I beg you, forgive the transgressions of your brothers and their sin. For they did evil to you.” ’ Now, please forgive the transgressions of the servants of the God of your father.” And Joseph wept when they spoke to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his brothers also went and fell down before his face and said, “We are your servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to them, “Do not be afraid, for am I in the place of God?
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you, you intended to harm me, but God intended it for good, in order to bring it about as it is this day, to save many lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, do not fear. I will provide for you and your little ones.” So he comforted them and spoke kindly to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph stayed in Egypt, he and his father’s household, and Joseph lived one hundred and ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph saw Ephraim’s children to the third generation. Also, the children of Makir, the son of Manasseh, were brought up on Joseph’s knees.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am about to die. God will surely come to you and bring you out of this land to the land of which He swore to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph made the sons of Israel swear, saying, “God will surely visit you, and you shall carry up my bones from here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph died at the age of one hundred and ten years old, and they embalmed him, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator
